{{Infobox tennis event|1990|Estoril Open| | main_name=Portugal Open{{!}}Estoril Open | date=2–8 April (men)
16–22 July (women) | edition=1st(ATP) / 2nd(WTA) | category=[[ATP World Series]] (men)
[[WTA Tier V tournaments|Tier V]] (women) | draw=32S/16D | prize_money=$225,000 (men)
$100,000 (women) | surface=[[Clay court|Clay]] / outdoor | location=[[Oeiras Municipality, Portugal|Oeiras]], Portugal | venue=[[Estoril Court Central]] | champms={{flagicon|ESP}} [[Emilio Sánchez]] {{cite web|title=1990 Estoril Men's Singles draw|url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/scores/archive/oeiras/468/1990/draws?matchType=singles|website=www.atpworldtour.com|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]] (ATP)}} | champws={{flagicon|ITA}} [[Federica Bonsignori]] | champmd={{flagicon|ESP}} [[Sergio Casal]] / {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Emilio Sánchez]] {{cite web|title=1990 Estoril Men's Doubles draw|url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/scores/archive/oeiras/468/1990/draws?matchType=doubles|website=www.atpworldtour.com|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]] (ATP)}} | champwd={{flagicon|ITA}} [[Sandra Cecchini]] / {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Patricia Tarabini]] }} The '''1990 Estoril Open''' was a combined men's and women's [[tennis]] tournament played on [[Clay court|outdoor red clay courts]]. It was the first edition of the event [[Portugal Open|Estoril Open]] for the men (the 2nd for the women), and was part of the [[ATP World Series]] of the [[1990 ATP Tour]]. It took place at the [[Estoril Court Central]], in [[Oeiras Municipality, Portugal|Oeiras]], [[Portugal]], from 2 April through 8 April 1990 for the men's tournament and from 16 July through 22 July 1990 for the women's tournament. [[Emilio Sánchez]] and [[Federica Bonsignori]] won the singles titles. ==Finals== ===Men's Singles=== {{main|1990 Estoril Open – Singles}} {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Emilio Sánchez]] defeated {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Franco Davín]] 6–3, 6–1 *It was Sánchez's second singles title of the year, and the 11th of his career. ===Women's Singles=== {{main|1990 Estoril Open – Women's Singles}} {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Federica Bonsignori]] defeated {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Laura Garrone]] 2–6, 6–3, 6–3 ===Men's Doubles=== {{main|1990 Estoril Open – Doubles}} {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Sergio Casal]] / {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Emilio Sánchez]] defeated {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Omar Camporese]] / {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Paolo Canè]] 7–5, 4–6, 7–5 *It was Casal's first doubles title of the year, and the 25th of his career. *It was Sánchez's second doubles title of the year, and the 28th of his career. ===Women's Doubles=== {{main|1990 Estoril Open – Women's Doubles}} {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Sandra Cecchini]] / {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Patricia Tarabini]] defeated {{flagicon|NED}} [[Carin Bakkum]] / {{flagicon|NED}} [[Nicole Muns-Jagerman]] 1–6, 6–2, 6–3 ==References== {{reflist}} *http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/tournaments/estoril/7290/overview ==External links== * [http://www.itftennis.com/procircuit/tournaments/men's-tournament/info.aspx?tournamentid=1010004752 International Tennis Federation (ITF) men's tournament edition details] * [http://www.itftennis.com/procircuit/tournaments/women's-tournament/info.aspx?tournamentid=1020000514 International Tennis Federation (ITF) women's tournament edition details] * [http://www.wtatennis.com/SEWTATour-Archive/Archive/Draws/1990/1054.pdf Women's Tennis Association (WTA) tournament edition details] {{Estoril Open tournaments}} {{1990 ATP Tour}} {{1990 WTA Tour}} {{1990 in tennis}} [[Category:Portugal Open]] [[Category:1990 ATP Tour|Estoril]] [[Category:1990 WTA Tour|Estoril]] [[Category:1990 in Portuguese sport|Estoril Open]] {{portugal-sport-stub}} {{tennis-competition-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Lead too short|date=September 2009}} '''Biribol''' is a sport, which resembles an aquatic variation of [[volleyball]]. It has originated in Brazil, in the city of [[Birigüi]], in the 1960s by Prof. Dario Miguel Pedro. It showed up as a group game and as an alternative to the practice and the learning of swimming. It is the newest sports modality in Brazil and the only group sport genuinely Brazilian, born and instituted inside the country.<ref>{{cite web |title = História do Biribol |url = http://www.educarede.org.br/educa/index.cfm?pg=galeria_de_arte.detalhe_texto&id_galeria=32&id_arte=1635&id_comunidade=1 |author = Montoro, Patricia |date = 2005-06-14 |publisher = EducaRede |accessdate = 2008-08-15}}</ref>
==Field== [[File:Biribol field.jpg|right|thumb|500px|Biribol field]] Its game is played inside a pool which size is 8m length, 4m width and 1.30m depth (the depth must be this for the entire pool) with a net in the middle of the pool with 2.62m high for the male and with 2.40m high for the female practice. The game space is constituted by 7m high measured from the surface of the water. There is also an attack area, delimited by a line which cross the pool by 1.25m from where the net is in each side. There are lines that delimit the service area, by the end of the pool, 1m from its length limit and other 0.8m from its width limit.<ref>{{cite web |title = Instalações e Equipamentos |url = http://www.biribol.com/interna.asp?id=19 |work = Liga Nacional de Biribol |accessdate = 2008-08-15}}</ref>
==Rules==
===Game ball=== The ball is specially crafted ball similar to that of [[water polo]] but with a smaller diameter. The ball weights approximately 100 grams more than the volleyball one and employs a "super grip" surface technology. The official game is played with four players on each side, but there is also the doubles modality, with two players on each side. Biribol is a highly recommended sport for working all muscle groups with practically no injury risks due to its no contact, low impact on joints nature. Biribol is also suited for all ages and genders, and is recommended for people with minor chronic injuries that feel discomfort or pain while playing other sports.
===Game play=== Matches are decided in best-of-three or best-of-five sets of 21 points, when the matches go up to the last set this set is disputed up to the 20th point instead, and a team needs at least two points of advantage in any circumstance to win a set. So if a 21-points set is drawn at 20x20, the match is extended to 22 points, and so on. [[Image:Biriball.jpg|left|thumb|300px|A practice of Biribol in [[São Paulo (state)|São Paulo]]]] The ball can be touched with any part of the player's body, with open or closed hands. The pool's inside borders are neutral, meaning the ball is normally in play after touching them, points are scored when the ball hits the water in the opponents' side or the opponent team commits a fault. As in volleyball, each team can contact the ball no more than three times before the ball crosses the net, while consecutive contacts must be made by different players - except for contacts while blocking, which are not counted. Players also cannot touch the net or they commit a fault and a point is awarded to the opponent team. Unique to the sport is that there is no penetration under ''and'' over the net - it is even allowed to block a set being executed in the opponents' side -, the possibility of blocking serves and how there is no lifting (carrying) faults during spikes.
With its fast moving, highly accurate ball and 'closed quarters' action, Biribol is also an extremely competitive sport and enjoys a popularity similar to or greater than [[water volleyball]] in southern Brazil. There is currently a Brazilian National League <ref>{{cite web |title = Brazilian National Biriball League |url = http://www.biribol.com/ |work = Liga Nacional de Biribol |accessdate = 2009-02-19}}</ref> with teams from [[São Paulo (state)|São Paulo]], [[Minas Gerais]], [[Mato Grosso do Sul]], [[Goias]] and [[Paraná (state)|Paraná]]. There are many stages held in different cities of the country, and the Brazilian champion is known in the end of the year, after computing all points of the season. The sport has been reckoned officially in the state of [[São Paulo]], and grows rapidly in the country.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://abrab.org.br/ Brazilian Biribol Association]
{{Team Sport}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | name = Cardines Field | nickname = | image = | fullname = | former_names = Basin Field | location = 20 America's Cup Avenue, [[Newport, Rhode Island|Newport]], [[Rhode Island]], [[United States of America|USA]] | coordinates = {{Coord|41.491006|-71.316861|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = 1908 | built = | opened = | renovated = 1938, 2000 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of Newport, RI | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = Electric | construction_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 3,000{{cite book | last =Lima | first =Nicholas | title =Newport Gulls 2016 Media Guide | publisher =Newport Gulls | location =[[Newport, Rhode Island|Newport, RI]] | page =7 | jfm = }}| record_attendance = | dimensions =Leftfield: 315 ft
Left Centerfield: 365 ft
Centerfield: 395 ft
Centerfield Indent: 315 ft
Right Centerfield Corner: 340 ft
Right Field: 285 ft
Fences: 28 ft | tenants = [[Newport Gulls]] ([[New England Collegiate Baseball League|NECBL]]) ([[2001 NECBL season|2001]]-present) [[Salve Regina University#Athletics/sports|Salve Regina Seahawks]] ([[Commonwealth Coast Conference|CCC]]) }} '''Cardines Field''' is a [[baseball]] stadium located at 20 America’s Cup Avenue in [[Newport, Rhode Island]]. It is believed to be one of the oldest [[Baseball park|ballparks]] in the [[United States]] and has been called "a small urban gem of a ballpark".Jeffery Staats quoted in ''Field of Dreams'' The field serves as a buffer between the residential and commercial sections of an older part of Newport. The oddly shaped outfield fence and dimensions are created by the close proximity of residential housing, while the spectator side of the park is contained by [[Route 238 (Rhode Island)|America's Cup Avenue]] and West Marlborough Street.Wikimapia Originally called '''Basin Field''', references to the field can be found as early as 1893. At that time, the property was used by local [[Rail transport|railroads]] as a drainage and supply basin for steam engines. Complaints from neighbors about the [[stagnant water]] and [[mosquito]]es prompted the drainage of the basin area, permitting baseball to be played. A local historical debate continues as to whether baseball was played prior to 1900, making Cardines one of the oldest existing ballparks in the country, or if play didn't begin until 1908, the earliest documented proof of [[stadium]] construction. The Basin Field ballpark was later renamed for Bernardo Cardines, a Newport baseball player who was Newport's first citizen to die in [[World War I]]. Today, the ballpark continues to be the home of the historic [[George Donnelly Sunset League|Sunset League]], as well as the [[Newport Gulls]] of the [[New England Collegiate Baseball League]]. ==History== Built for unofficial [[sandlot baseball]] games by railroad workers from the adjacent [[Old Colony Railroad|Old Colony Division of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Line]], the field hosted many barnstorming all-stars, including [[Negro League]] teams like the [[Baltimore Elite Giants]], [[Boston Royal Giants]] and the [[New York Black Yankees]]. [[Satchel Paige]] once played at Cardines. The original backstop dates back to as early as 1908, when the city organized its first six-team league at the park.Field of Dreams Cardines Field is a smaller cousin of other notable ballparks of that era, such as [[Ebbets Field]], [[Fenway Park]] and [[Wrigley Field]], with a stone facade and wooden bleachers with unique outfield angles. The exterior's elliptical arches reflect the facade of the original [[Yankee Stadium (1923)|Yankee Stadium]]. In 1936, the city of Newport took over ownership. Stone and concrete bleachers were built along the third-base line by the [[Works Progress Administration]] (WPA) in 1936-1937. The plaque at the entrance that reads "1937" refers to this date. The current grandstand was built by the [[Works Progress Administration|WPA]] following the devastating hurricane of 1938. The distinctive curving grandstand section behind home plate was built in 1939. Over the coming decades, the park continued to grow through construction projects to increase capacity, eventually creating the patchwork, overlapping stadium seen today. During [[World War II]], many former professional ball players were stationed at [[Naval Station Newport]]. Many of these players, including [[Yogi Berra]], [[Phil Rizzuto]], and [[Bob Feller]] participated in Newport's [[George Donnelly Sunset League]], an amateur league formed in 1919. Wednesday night all-star games drew thousands and required construction of temporary bleachers in the outfield. The Sunset League was named because games began at 5:30 p.m. and ended at dusk, prior to the addition of lights at the park. It is the oldest continuous amateur baseball league in the country. With black players such as [[Larry Doby]] and [[Luke Easter (baseball player)|Luke Easter]], the Sunset League was integrated several years before [[Jackie Robinson]] joined the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947. The league continues today as key chapter of Cardines' history. ==Current tenants== The [[George Donnelly Sunset League|Sunset League]] still plays a full schedule throughout the summer, though the park's lighting system now permits games to go well beyond dusk. The field is home to baseball games for [[Rogers High School (Newport, Rhode Island)|Rogers High School]], Newport's [[Babe Ruth League]], the historic Sunset League, Newport's [[American Legion]] team, [[Salve Regina University]], [[Naval Academy Preparatory School]] and the [[Newport Gulls]] of the [[New England Collegiate Baseball League]]. In the January 18, 2004 edition of [[Baseball America]], Cardines Field was chosen as one of the top five locations in America to play college summer baseball, in response to the jump in reputation the Gulls brought to the park. ==Newport Gulls era== [[Image:Cardinesfield.jpg|thumb|Cardines undergoing pregame preparation on a Gulls game night.]] While most teams playing at Cardines average attendance in the dozens or, at most, a few hundred per game, the [[Newport Gulls]], since moving to Newport in [[2001 NECBL season|2001]], have helped to bring the field back to its former glory days of the mid-20th century, attracting hundreds of fans every night. During the [[2004 NECBL season|2004 regular and playoff seasons]] alone, the Gulls attracted over 50,000 fans through just 26 home games, often with sellout crowds. Following the [[2010 NECBL season|2010 season]], the Gulls set a team and NECBL record for regular season home attendance, totaling 45,683 after 21 games.{{cite book | last =Lima | first =Nicholas | title =Newport Gulls 2013 Media Guide | publisher =Newport Gulls | location =[[Newport, Rhode Island|Newport, RI]] | page =64 | jfm = }} ==Renovations== Renovation work began in 2000 with funds from a matching $500,000 grant from the state [[RI DEM|Department of Environmental Management]] and the formation of the Friends of Cardines Field Foundation. In recent years, the grandstands, concession operation, and bathrooms have been renovated as part of the project, along with the addition of a state-of-the-art field lighting system. The winter of 2005 - 2006 saw the entire outfield and infield replaced among other improvements, including the addition of a fully functional drainage system and new outfield fence, all at the cost of an additional half million dollars.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927195721/http://www.eastbayri.com/story/318548899310862.php] The Newport Gulls also have necessitated the expansion of concession equipment, in addition to the renovation of a team office, storage rooms, souvenir stand, ticket booth, scoreboard, and public address system, much of which has been covered by the ongoing restoration project led by the city's Parks and Recreation Department, the Gulls former ownership, and [[Roger Williams University]] Professor Jeffery Staats. The most recent improvements have been to upgrade the stadium's broadcasting abilities, with the addition of high speed Internet and phone lines, camera positions, and a control room below the pressbox for use by the Tigers TV Crew, the volunteer production crew who work with the Gulls to produce games. The park today has changed drastically in upkeep and appearance from that of the recent past. As early as a decade ago, some in the city of Newport had proposed for a then dilapidated Cardines Field to be demolished in order to expand parking in the cramped downtown area, a mere block in each direction from the waterfront to the West, commercial and tourist center to the South, and world-famous historical district to the East. Future projects at Cardines include: concluding outfield fence replacement via a state grant, widening and lengthening of the hockey-style side-by-side dugouts, the additions of a locker room and an umpire's room, and further restoration of bleachers, framework, trim, and other facets. The removal of a large, rundown private warehouse which makes up the right field fouline has been discussed for some time, though no official plans have been announced. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *{{Cite web | url = http://www.preservationnation.org/magazine/story-of-the-week/2004/field-of-dreams.html | title = Field of Dreams | work = Preservation Online: Story of the Week (2004) | publisher = National Trust for Historic Preservation | date = 12 March 2004 | accessdate = 21 July 2010 }} * [http://wikimapia.org/1684963/Cardine-s-Field Wikimapia] — Aerial view of Cardines Field ==External links== {{Portal|Rhode Island}} * [http://www.newportgulls.com Newport Gulls] — Newport Gulls Official Site. * [http://www.necbl.com NECBL] — New England Collegiate Baseball League Official Site. * [http://www.teamline.cc/options.html?teamcode=6308&eventcode=0025 Teamline]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Newport Gulls Broadcasts. * [http://www.digitalballparks.com/NECBL/Newport.html Digitalballparks] Walkthrough of the history and images of Cardines Field, taken after 2001, prior to most major renovations having taken place. * [http://www.projectballpark.org/other/cardines.html Project Ballpark] Cardines Field in 2007 * [http://mysite.verizon.net/charliesballparks/stadiums/cardines.htm Charlie's Ballparks] Cardines Field in 2001 {{NECBL Ballparks}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Rhode Island]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Newport, Rhode Island]] [[Category:Landmarks in Rhode Island]] [[Category:New England Collegiate Baseball League ballparks]] [[Category:Salve Regina University]] [[Category:Works Progress Administration in Rhode Island]] [[Category:1908 establishments in Rhode Island]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1908]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:High school baseball venues in the United States]]

{{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Hesketh Park | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | country = England | location = [[Dartford]], [[Kent]] | coordinates = {{coord|51.439|N|0.235|E|type:landmark|display=title, inline}} | establishment = 1905 | demolished = | last used = | seating_capacity = | owner = [[Dartford Borough Council]] | architect = | contractor = | operator = | tenants = | home club = [[Dartford Cricket Club]] | end1 = | end2 = | year1 = 1905–present | club1 = [[Dartford Cricket Club]] | year2 = 1956–1990 | club2 = [[Kent County Cricket Club]] | date = 6 September | year = 2010 | source = https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/449.html CricketArchive }}
'''Hesketh Park''' is a [[cricket]] ground in [[Dartford]] in [[Kent]]. The ground is the home of [[Dartford Cricket Club]], one of the oldest cricket clubs in the United Kingdom. The ground was established at the beginning of the 20th century and has been used as a [[first-class cricket]] venue by [[Kent County Cricket Club]].
The ground is located around {{convert|1|mi|km}} south-east of Dartford town centre and is one f the few open spaces which remain on what was once the [[Dartford Brent]]. The [[A296 road]] runs along the western side of the ground with the [[A225 road]] to the south and the [[Dartford Crossing|A282 Dartford Crossing approach road]] running {{convert|250|m|mi}} east of the ground.<ref name=osx162>Explorer Map 162 – Greenwich & Gravesend, [[Ordnance Survey]], 2015-09-16.</ref>
==Establishment== Cricket has been played at Dartford since at least the early 18th century and Dartford Cricket Club is one of the oldest established cricket clubs in England.<ref name=dcchistory>[http://www.dartfordcc.co.uk/our-history/club-history Our history: Cricket in Dartford], [[Dartford Cricket Club]]. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref> Cricket was first played on [[Dartford Brent]], an area of common land to the east of the town on which the modern Hesketh Park ground is situated. The earliest known match between two county sides took place on the Brent in 1709 with a [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent team]] playing [[Surrey county cricket teams|one from Surrey]]. After the end of the 18th century matches moved to [[Bowman's Lodge]] on [[Dartford Heath]] before Hesketh Park was established at the start of the 20th century.<ref name=dccbrent>[http://www.dartfordcc.co.uk/our-history/dartford-brent Our history: Dartford Brent], [[Dartford Cricket Club]]. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref>
An area of municipal park land was established at Hesketh Park in 1904 as a result of a donation by local businessman [[Everand Hesketh]]. The site was expanded in 1905 when Hesketh purchased land adjacent to the park to build a sports ground which includes the cricket ground. The first match on the ground was held in 1905, with Hesketh bowling the first over.<ref name=dccpark>[http://www.dartfordcc.co.uk/our-history/hesketh-park Our history: Hesketh Park], [[Dartford Cricket Club]]. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref> The ground is owned by [[Dartford Borough Council]] and operated by the council and Dartford Cricket Club.<ref name=dccpav>[http://www.dartfordcc.co.uk/about-the-club/new-pavilion-project Hesketh Park Pavilion project], [[Dartford Cricket Club]]. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref><ref name=ko25feb15>[http://www.kentonline.co.uk/dartford/news/howzat-cricket-club-set-for-32490/ Dartford Cricket Club set to move to new pavilion in Hesketh Park ahead of new season], ''[[Kent Online]]'', 2015-02-25. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref><ref name=milton>Milton H (1979) Kent cricket grounds, in ''The Cricket Statistician'', no.28, December 1979, pp.2–10.</ref>
==Cricket history== [[Kent County Cricket Club]] used Hesketh Park for First XI fixtures between 1956 and 1990. The first [[first-class cricket]] match on the ground took place in May 1956 and saw Kent play [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]]. A total of 33 first-class matches were held on the ground, with Kent playing a [[County Championship]] fixture at Dartford in most seasons from 1956 until 1990.<ref name=17annual210>Grounds Records in ''Kent County Cricket Club Annual 2017'', pp.210–211. Canterbury: [[Kent County Cricket Club]].</ref> In 1963 the county played twice at the ground, a Championship match against [[Northamptonshire County Cricket Club|Northants]] followed by a match against the [[Pakistan Eaglets]] – a touring side of younger Pakistani cricketers. The final first-class match on the ground was held in August 1990 with [[Leicestershire County Cricket Club|Leicestershire]] as the opposition.<ref name=dccpark /><ref name=cafc>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/449_f.html First-class Matches played on Hesketh Park, Dartford], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref>
Kent have also played two [[List-A cricket]] matches on the ground, both against Essex. The first match took place in the [[1978 Benson & Hedges Cup]] and the second in the [[1981 Benson & Hedges Cup|1981 tournament]]. <ref name=calista>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/449_a.html List-A Matches played on Hesketh Park, Dartford], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref> The Kent Second XI also used the ground 40 times between 1947, when they played [[Norfolk County Cricket Club|Norfolk]] in the [[Minor Counties Championship]], and 1995 when it was used in the [[Second XI Championship]].<ref name=ca>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/449.html Hesketh Park, Dartford], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref>
During the [[1973 Women's Cricket World Cup]] the ground was used for a single [[Women's One Day International cricket|Women's One Day International]]. [[Australia women's cricket team|Australia women]] beat [[New Zealand women's cricket team|New Zealand women]] on the ground with Australian opening batsman [[Bev Wilson]] scoring a half-century.<ref name=women>[http://www.espncricinfo.com/series/8584/game/66875/Australia-Women-vs-New-Zealand-Women-9th-Match-womens-world-cup Australia Women vs New-Zealand Women – scorecard], [[CricInfo]]. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref>
In local domestic cricket the ground has been the home venue of [[Dartford Cricket Club]] since it was established in 1905. The club plays in the [[Kent Cricket League]]. The [[cricket pavilion|pavilion]] on the ground was replaced in 2015, the new building replacing one which had been built in the 1980s to replace the original pavilion which had been built when the ground was established but was later destroyed by fire.<ref name=dccpav /> The pavilion project was part funded by [[Dartford Borough Council]] with a grant of £1 million. A new area of cricket nets was built on the ground as part of the project.<ref name=dccpav /><ref name=ko25feb15 /><ref name=ko11jun14>[http://www.kentonline.co.uk/dartford/news/council-to-approve-1m-funding-18431/ Council to approve £1m funding for new pavilion at Dartford Cricket Club], ''[[Kent Online]]'', 2014-06-11. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref> The ground has also hosted fixtures involving [[Lashings World XI]].<ref name=ko3jul08>[http://www.kentonline.co.uk/dartford/sport/students-face-legendary-tendulke-a40489/ Students face legendary Tendulker], ''[[Kent Online]]'', 2008-07-03. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref><ref name=ko29jun17>[http://www.kentonline.co.uk/dartford/sport/the-full-monty-128017/ Monty Panesar and Shivnarine Chanderpaul playing for Lashings All-Stars at Dartford CC], ''[[Kent Online]]'', 2017-06-29. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref>
==Records on the ground== A total of 33 first-class and two List A matches were held on the ground, all with Kent as the home team.<ref name=cafc /> *Highest total: 476 by [[Kent County Cricket Club|Kent]] against [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]], 1985 *Lowest total: 65 by [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]] against Kent, 1988 *Highest partnership: 231, 3rd wicket by [[Harry Pilling|H Pilling]] and [[Clive Lloyd|CH Lloyd]], for [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] against Kent, 1970 *Highest individual score: 204 [[not out]], [[Alan Ormrod|JA Ormrod]], for [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire]] against Kent, 1973 *Best bowling in an innings: 8/39, [[Fred Ridgway|F Ridgway]], for Kent against Nottinghamshire, 1960 *Best bowling in a match: 12/101, F Ridgway, for Kent against Nottinghamshire, 1960 In the two List A matches on the ground the highest team score was 226/4 scored by Kent chasing an Essex score of 222 in 1978. The highest individual score was 79 not out, scored by [[Bob Woolmer]] for Kent in 1981 in another successful run chase against Essex.<ref name=ca /> The highest women's individual score on the ground was 50 runs scored by [[Bev Wilson]].<ref name=ca />
==Other sports== Hesketh Park is the home of Dartford [[bowls]] club. Grass and hard [[tennis]] courts are also available in the wider park.<ref name=dbc>[https://www.dartford.gov.uk/by-category/leisure-and-culture2/parks-and-open-spaces/heskethpark Hesketh Park], [[Dartford Borough Council]]. Retrieved 2017-11-28.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.cricinfo.com/england/content/ground/56951.html Hesketh Park] at [[Cricinfo]] *[http://www.dartfordcc.co.uk Dartford Cricket Club]
{{Kent CCC}} [[Category:Cricket grounds in Kent]] [[Category:Borough of Dartford]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1943]]

revision.text:
The '''metabolic window''' (also called the anabolic window) is a term used in [[strength training]] to describe the 30-minute (give or take, dependent on the individual) period after exercise during which nutrition can shift the body from a [[Catabolism|catabolic]] state to an [[Anabolism|anabolic]] one. Specifically, it is during this period that the intake of [[protein]] and [[carbohydrates]] can aid in the increase of [[muscle mass]].<ref name=Ivy49>Ivy, John & Portman, Robert. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=04GJNEwE6zMC&pg=PA48&lpg=PA48&dq=%22metabolic+window%22&source=web&ots=njZIq94s1m&sig=3z831UWMuBUHjbZZL8vrVei2lOs&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result#PPA49,M1 Nutrient Timing: The Future of Sports Nutrition]''. Basic Health Publications, Inc., 2004.</ref>
Some theorists believe the metabolic window begins to close within minutes of the end of a workout. The same nutrients taken two hours later result in significantly reduced [[protein synthesis]] and muscle [[glycogen]] storage.<ref name=Ivy49/> Further research is needed into the effects of food and exercise timing, but methodology has to be considered in these experiments.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/17461390801919102 | title=Protein for adaptations to exercise training | publisher=European Journal of Sport Science | work=Volume 8, Issue 2 | year=2008 | accessdate=April 8, 2012 | author=Tipton, Kevin D.}}</ref>
Currently there is not sufficient scientific evidence to support the metabolic window theory.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Aragon|first=Alan Albert|last2=Schoenfeld|first2=Brad Jon|date=2013-01-29|title=Nutrient timing revisited: is there a post-exercise anabolic window?|journal=Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition|volume=10|pages=5|doi=10.1186/1550-2783-10-5|issn=1550-2783|pmc=3577439|pmid=23360586}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Anaerobic exercise]] * [[Bodybuilding]] * [[Powerlifting]] * [[Resistance training (disambiguation)|Resistance training]] * [[Weight training|Weightlifting]]
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Metabolic Window}} [[Category:Physical exercise]] [[Category:Exercise physiology]]
{{Weightlifting-stub}} {{bodybuilding-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Nadderud | image = [[File:Nadderud stadion-main stand.jpg|300px]] | fullname = Nadderud stadion| nickname = | location = [[Nadderud]], [[Bærum]], [[Norway]] | coordinates= {{Coord|59|55|16|N|10|34|52|E|display=inline,title}} | owner = [[Bærum|Bærum municipality]] | operator = [[Stabæk Fotball]] | surface = [[Turf management#Football pitches|grass]] | built = | opened = 1961 | seating_capacity = 5,000 | tenants = [[Stabæk Fotball]] (football)
[[IL Tyrving]] (track and field)
'''Former tenants:'''
[[Bærum SK]] (football) | dimensions = | }} '''Nadderud stadion''' is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] at [[Nadderud]] near [[Bekkestua]], in [[Bærum]], Norway. ==Association football== It is currently used mostly for track and field meets and [[association football|football]] matches, and is the home ground of the Norwegian [[Toppserien]] (women's) and [[Tippeligaen]] (men's) team [[Stabæk Fotball]]. Former tenants are [[Bærum SK]]. Matches for the [[Norway national under-21 football team|U-21 national team]] has also been played here. The record attendance is about 10,000, from a 1970 cup match where Stabæk played [[Strømsgodset IF|Strømsgodset]]. Ahead of the 1996 season, a new main grandstand with seating for 2,900 people was opened, costing 15 million [[Norwegian krone]] (NOK). It increased the seating at the stadium with 1,400 seats from the old grandstand.{{cite news |title=Nadderud stadion in "new look" |last=Nesbø |first=Knut |authorlink=Knut Nesbø |date=14 February 1996 |work=[[Aftenposten]] |page=15 |language=Norwegian}} The municipality installed [[floodlights (sport)|flood lights]] ahead of the 2005 season.{{cite news |title=Stabæk vant – får drømmearenaen|last=Hole |first=Arne |work=[[Aftenposten]] |date=30 October 2004 |page=18 |language=Norwegian}} Stabæk moved to [[Telenor Arena]] for the 2009 Premier League season, but is returning for the 2012 season. In a 2012 survey carried out by the [[Norwegian Players' Association]] among away-team captains, Nadderud was ranked twelfth amongst league stadiums, with a score of 2.73 on a scale from one to five.{{cite news |url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/nrk_trondelag/1.8836297 |title=Lerkendal nest beste fotballbane |publisher=[[Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=28 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CYl4tTGG?url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/nrk_trondelag/1.8836297 |language=Norwegian |archivedate=30 November 2012 |accessdate=30 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} From 2009 the stadium is the home pitch of Stabæk's women's team [[Stabæk Fotball Kvinner]] (SFK), who play in the elite [[Toppserien]] league. Before the start of the 2012 season, Stabæk Fotball has moved back to Nadderud and the team's NPL matches will be played at the stadium. This follows a decline in fortune of the top tier team, who were not able to pay for their rent for Telenor Arena past the end of 2011. ==Athletics== The stadium hosted the [[European Cup in Athletics]], First League for Men, in 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/epb.htm|title=European Cup B Final and First League|work=GBR Athletics|publisher=Athletics Weekly|accessdate=13 May 2011}} Domestically it has hosted the Norwegian Championships in 1966 (arranged by ([[IL Tyrving]]) and 1985 (arranged by ([[Fossum IF]]).{{cite web |url=http://www.friidrett.no/stevner/statistikk/nm/Documents/amnm.htm |title=Main Championships Men |publisher=[[Norwegian Athletics Association]] |language=Norwegian |accessdate=25 November 2011 |archivedate=25 November 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63SxANU6u?url=http://www.friidrett.no/stevner/statistikk/nm/Documents/amnm.htm |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} It annually hosts the country's largest track and field meet, Tyrvinglekene. ==Bandy== The Norwegian [[bandy]] final was held here on 22 February 1970 when [[Strømsgodset IF]] under a heavy snowfall beat [[Stabæk Bandy|Stabæk IF]] 3–1. ==References== {{commons category|Nadderud stadion}} {{reflist}} {{Stabæk IF}} {{Norwegian Premier League venues}} {{Norwegian Women's Premier League venues}} {{Portal bar|Association football|Athletics|Norway}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nadderud Stadion}} [[Category:Football venues in Norway]] [[Category:Eliteserien venues]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Norway]] [[Category:Sports venues in Bærum]] [[Category:Stabæk IF]] [[Category:Bærum SK]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1961]] [[Category:1961 establishments in Norway]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Norway]]

revision.text:
'''Offside''' is a minor [[penalty (American football)|foul]] in [[gridiron football]] caused when a defender crosses the [[line of scrimmage]] ahead of the snap of the ball. The penalty associated with the infraction is the advancing of the ball five yards and a replay of the down.
==History==
===Definition=== In [[gridiron football]], '''offside''' is a [[penalty (American football)|foul]] in which a player is on the wrong side of the [[line of scrimmage]] when the ball is snapped. This foul occurs simultaneously with the snap. Unlike offensive players, defensive players are not compelled to come to a set position before the snap. If a defender jumps across the line but gets back to his side before the snap, there is no foul. In the case of an offside foul, play is not stopped, and the foul is announced at the conclusion of the play. Media covering the games calls it a "free play" for the offense, as the non-offending team may decline the penalty and take the yardage gained on the play (and when the play works against them, like a turnover to the opposing team, the non-offending team can accept the penalty and retake possession of the ball)—unlike in the case of a [[false start]] foul against the offense, whereupon the play is immediately stopped by the officials.
This foul is almost always committed by the defense (any offensive player that moves into the neutral zone after setting would be charged with a false start). However, it is possible for the offense to commit this foul. If an offensive player lines up in the neutral zone, an offside foul will be called against the offense.
===Penalty===
Prior to 1925, a call of offside against a defensive unit brought with it an automatic [[first down]] in addition to a five-yard advancement of the ball for the offense.<ref name=same>Associated Press, [https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4638019/forward_pass_to_remain_just_same/ "Forward Pass to Remain Just Same,"] ''Corvallis [OR] Gazette-Times,'' vol. 16, no. 206 (Dec. 30, 1924), pg. 1.</ref> However, a December 1924 meeting of the [[Football Coaches' Association of America]] spurred a change of rules for the 1925 season eliminating the provision for an automatic first down, while leaving the five yard penalty intact.<ref name=same />
The penalty for violation remains 5 yards at most levels of professional and amateur play.
==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}}
{{Gridiron football penalties}}
[[Category:Gridiron football penalties]] [[Category:Sports offsides|American]]

{{Infobox university | name = Philippine Sports Institute | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Philippine Sports Institute logo.svg | image_size = 125px | image_upright = | image_alt = | caption = | latin_name = | other_name = | former_name = | motto = | motto_lang = | mottoeng = | top_free_label = | top_free = | type = | established = {{start date|1996}}–{{end date|1998}}
{{start date|2005}} | closed = {{end date|2009}}
{{start date|2016}}– |formation = | founder = | parent = [[Philippine Sports Commission]] | affiliation = | religious_affiliation = | academic_affiliation = | endowment = | budget = | officer_in_charge = | chairman = | chairperson = | head_label = National Training Director | head = Marc Velasco | academic_staff = | administrative_staff = | students = | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | other = | address = | city = [[Pasig]], [[Metro Manila]] | country = Philippines | postcode = | coordinates = | campus = | language = | free_label = | free = | free_label2 = | free2 = | colors = | athletics = | sports = | athletics_nickname = | sporting_affiliations = | mascot = | sports_free_label = | sports_free = | sports_free_label2 = | sports_free2 = | website = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | footnotes = }} The '''Philippine Sports Institute''' ('''PSI''') is a [[sports training]] organization in the Philippines. It is under the [[Philippine Sports Commission]]. ==History== The Philippine Sports Institute (PSI) was first launched in May 1996 as the Philippine Institute of Sports (PhilSports). Then President [[Fidel Ramos]] instructed then [[Philippine Sports Commission]] (PSC) Chairman Philip Ella Juico to form the sports institute which was inaugurated on November that year. With the help of former PSC Chairman Perry Mequi, Philsports organized various programs.{{cite news|last1=Henson|first1=Joaquin|title=Ending a 20-year wait|url=http://www.philstar.com/sports/2016/09/07/1621301/ending-20-year-wait|accessdate=25 January 2017|work=Sporting Chance|publisher=The Philippine Star|date=7 September 2016}} It was disestablished in 1998 by Juico's successor. Under the Republic Act 6847 of 1990, the PSC is mandated to run a sports institute alongside of maintaining a Philippine Sports Hall of Fame.{{cite news|last1=Bonilla|first1=Ramon Rafael|title=Duterte opens reestablished sports institute|url=http://www.businessmirror.com.ph/duterte-opens-reestablished-sports-institute/|accessdate=4 January 2017|work=BusinessMirror|date=4 January 2017}} The sports institute was briefly revived in 2005 by PSC Chairman William Ramirez under the administration of then President [[Gloria Macapagal Arroyo]] but was made defunct by Ramirez's successor. When Ramirez was appointed once again to the post by President [[Rodrigo Duterte]], the organization was revived once again. The PSI was reestablished two weeks before September 16, 2016.{{cite news|last1=Giongco|first1=Nick|title=PSC makes a move to end poor performance|url=http://2016.mb.com.ph/2016/09/16/psc-makes-a-move-to-end-poor-performance/|accessdate=4 January 2017|publisher=Manila Bulletin|date=16 September 2016}} The sports institute was patterned after the Canberra based [[Australian Institute of Sport]]. Marc Velasco was appointed as the first national training director of the PSI since its revival.{{cite news|last=Navarro|first=June|title=PSC enlists collegiate leagues' assistance|url=http://sports.inquirer.net/228913/psc-enlists-collegiate-leagues-assistance|accessdate=4 January 2017|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=10 November 2016}} On January 16, 2017, the PSI was formally launched at the [[PhilSports Arena]].{{cite news|last1=Bonilla|first1=Ramon Rafael|title=Philippine Sports Institute relaunched|url=http://www.businessmirror.com.ph/philippine-sports-institute-relaunched/|accessdate=16 January 2017|publisher=BusinessMirror|date=16 January 2017}} President [[Rodrigo Duterte]] was supposed to lead the ceremony, but did not make it due to prior commitments. Instead, Cabinet Secretary [[Leoncio Evasco]] was sent as the President's representative in the ceremony.{{cite news|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/psc-relaunches-ph-sports-institute/307275/|title=PSC relaunches PH Sports Institute|publisher=[[Manila Times]]|last=David|first=Jean Russel V.|date=January 16, 2017|accessdate=January 17, 2017}} PSC Chairman William Ramirez led the relaunch with Philippine Olympic Committee President [[Peping Cojuangco]] also in attendance. ==Programs== With support from the [[United States Sports Academy]], the PSI will provide Filipino officials international courses on sports management, coaching, and physical education.{{cite news|last1=Terrado|first1=Reuben|title=Philippine Sports Institute to offer international sports education courses|url=https://www.spin.ph/psc-poc/news/psc-psi-united-states-sports-academy-partnership-william-ramirez|accessdate=14 May 2018|work=Sports Interactive Network Philippines|date=10 May 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:1996 establishments in the Philippines]] [[Category:2005 establishments in the Philippines]] [[Category:2016 establishments in the Philippines]] [[Category:1998 disestablishments in the Philippines]] [[Category:National Institutes of Sport]] [[Category:Education in the Philippines]] [[Category:Sports organizations of the Philippines]] [[Category:Sport schools]]

{{For|the city park in Manchester, New Hampshire|Stark Park}} {{Refimprove|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox stadium | | stadium_name = Stark's Park| | image = [[Image:Starks Park. Kirkcaldy.jpg|250px|Stark's Park]]| | caption = The Main and South Stands of Stark's Park | pushpin_map = Scotland Fife | pushpin_mapsize = 250 | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Fife | pushpin_label_position = left |coordinates = {{coord|56|05|59.33|N|3|10|06.01|W|type:landmark|display=inline}} | location = [[Kirkcaldy]], Scotland | opened = 1891| | owner = [[Raith Rovers F.C.]] | surface = synthetic pitch | tenants = [[Raith Rovers F.C.]] | seating_capacity = {{SPFL-stadiums|raith}} (all seated)<ref name="capacity"/> }}
'''Stark's Park''' is a [[association football|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Kirkcaldy]], [[Scotland]]. It is the home ground of [[Raith Rovers F.C.|Raith Rovers]], who have played there since 1891. {{As of|2016}}, the ground has an all-seated capacity of {{SPFL-stadiums|raith}}.<ref name="capacity"/>
==History==
The ground was opened in 1891 (this is actually when Raith started using it, it has been around longer) and seats {{SPFL-stadiums|raith}}.<ref name="capacity">{{cite web |url=http://spfl.co.uk/clubs/raith/ |title=Raith Rovers Football Club|publisher=Scottish Professional Football League |accessdate=11 November 2013}}</ref> It is located in [[Kirkcaldy]], [[Fife]]. The park can clearly be seen from the railway line on the route between [[Edinburgh Waverley railway station|Edinburgh]] and [[Aberdeen railway station|Aberdeen]].
The unusual L-shaped main stand that houses the players dressing facilities and the supporters lounge was designed by the renowned ''Grandstand'' architect [[Archibald Leitch]] and was built with part funding from the sale of [[Alex James (footballer)|Alex James]] to [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] in 1925. Other funding came from a loan scheme that was not finally paid off until 1946. The terracing was open to the elements except for a covered enclosure affectionately known as the "coo shed" which stood opposite the main stand and ran approximately two-thirds of the length of the pitch. The ash and railway sleeper terracing which surrounded all sides of the ground except the stand enclosure was replaced with new concrete works in the north and south enclosures behind the goals. This work being carried out in the 1950s when a shed was erected at either end to give partial covering to the supporters. Typical of several football grounds of the time the club sold advertising space on the pitched asbestos roofs of the covered areas to companies such as R'bt Hutchison & Co (Youma Bread), The Evening Dispatch, Nelsons Cigarettes and Barnett & Morton Ltd, the local ironmonger who had erected the sheds. Shortly after the above terrace was upgraded, four large floodlighting pylons similar to those at [[Tynecastle Stadium|Tynecastle Park]] were erected to allow evening midweek fixtures to be played all year round. Most of the cost of the above work was covered (as had become the norm) by the sale of assets, the most notable of those being [[Jackie Stewart (footballer born 1921)|Jackie Stewart]] to [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], [[Jim Baxter]] to [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] and [[Jimmy MacEwan]] to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], the latter deal also leading to Villa travelling north to play in the first match under the new lights.
[[Image:Alec James signing fee.jpg|thumb|left|Alex James' share of the transfer fee which helped fund the main stand.]] The ground then remained unchanged for almost thirty years until the departure of a modern-day Alex James in the form of striker [[Andy Harrow]] who in 1981 was sold to [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]]. The sale of this latest asset allowed the board to demolish the antiquated railway enclosure and build a 1,000 seat stand on the south side and terraced concrete steps at the north side. This was how the ground was to remain until more redevelopment in the early 1990s. Anticipating a swift return after relegation from the Premier league in 1992 the board spent £250,000 on upgrading the north and south ends of the ground when the 1950s concrete was taken up and new terracing and crush barriers erected, although the sheds remained. Though the board's confidence in achieving promotion was well founded the money spent was to prove a poor investment as after the last home game of season 1995–96 the bulldozers returned and demolished both ends of the ground and the railway enclosure.
[[Barr Construction]] were appointed to redevelop the stadium. Two 3,370 seat stands with inbuilt floodlight towers behind each goal and a 1000-seat stand to join onto the 1980s railway (new) stand were erected. This work brought the ground capacity up to a creditable 10,700 all seater. During all of the above changes the main pavilion remained totally unchanged with its asbestos roof, concrete steps and wooden seats and benches. A new metal roof and plastic seating were finally installed in 1999 which slightly reduced the spectator capacity to 8,473. As of the 2017/2018 season the railway stand is to be converted into a standing support section adding to the total capacity which will become 11198.
In the 2018 [[Season_(sports)#Off-season|close season]], a synthetic pitch was laid.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifetoday.co.uk/sport/football/raith-rovers/gallery-new-pitch-progress-at-stark-s-park-1-4744473|title=Gallery: New pitch progress at Stark’s Park|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thecourier.co.uk/fp/news/local/fife/627814/raith-rovers-given-green-light-for-synthetic-surface-at-starks-park/|title=Raith Rovers given green light for synthetic surface at Stark's Park - The Courier|publisher=}}</ref>
[[Image:San Starko.JPG|thumb|right|Stark's Park from the south. |alt=Football stadium with fields and trees in the foreground and town of Kirkcaldy in the background.]]
==Nickname== The ground is often referred to by fans as the ''San Starko'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Raith Rovers|url=http://www.footballgroundguide.com/scotland/raith_rovers.html|work=Scottish Football Ground Guide|accessdate=11 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=San Starko |url=http://www.fifelink.com/raith/ |publisher=FifeLink |accessdate=23 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711000123/http://www.fifelink.com/raith/ |archivedate=11 July 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.raithrovers.net/starks-park|title=Stark’s Park - Raith Rovers FC|website=www.raithrovers.net}}</ref> in jesting reference to the [[San Siro]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.raithrovers.net/starks-park Section on Stark's Park at the official Raith Rovers site]
*[http://www.scottish-football-historical-archive.co.nf/fieldsoffife.pdf Scottish Football Historical Archive, p82]

page.title: United Kingdom football sexual abuse scandal

revision.comment: /* 2018 trial and conviction */ High Court of Justice
revision.text:
A '''[[Child sexual abuse in the United Kingdom|sexual abuse]] scandal''' involving the abuse of young players at [[Association football|football]] clubs in the [[United Kingdom]] began in mid-November 2016. The revelations began when former professional [[association football|football]]ers waived their rights to [[anonymity]] and talked publicly about being abused by former [[coach (sport)#association football)|coaches]] and [[Scout (association football)|scouts]] in the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s. This led to a surge of further allegations, as well as allegations that some clubs had covered them up.
Echoing similar revelations in the 1990s, the initial 2016 allegations centred on abuse of young players at [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] and [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] due to the clubs' associations with Barry Bennell (previously convicted of sexual abuse offences in the UK and US) who, on 29 November 2016, was charged with new offences. Allegations were also made against George Ormond, a former [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] youth coach and scout (who also had previous convictions), former [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] scout Eddie Heath, and former [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough]] coach Bob Higgins. In early December 2016, allegations about former youth coaches and scouts in Northern Ireland and Scotland also started to emerge.
Within a month of the initial reporting, the [[The Football Association|Football Association]], the [[Scottish Football Association]], several football clubs and over 20 UK police forces had established various inquiries and investigations and over 350 alleged victims had come forward. By July 2018, 300 suspects were reported to have been identified by 849 alleged victims, with 2,807 incidents involving 340 different clubs. These have led to 13 individuals being charged with historical sexual abuse, of which nine have been tried: seven - Bennell, Ormond, William Toner, Michael Coleman, Jim McCafferty, Robert Smith and James Torbett - have been convicted and jailed; Higgins has been found guilty of one charge and faces a retrial on 48 further charges; Paul McCann was cleared. Gerald King is currently on trial, two await trial, and one has since died. Other allegations involve individuals who had died prior to the revelations.
In July 2018, the FA's independent inquiry was said to have found no evidence of an institutional cover-up or of a paedophile ring operating within football, but intended publication of its report in September 2018 was delayed, potentially by up to a year, pending the retrial of Higgins and possible further charges against Bennell.
==Implicated individuals== The sexual abuse allegations related to several publicly identified individuals, listed below in the order of which they were named as the scandal developed from late 2016, through 2017 and into 2018 (some individuals, including Bennell, Ormond, Langford and Torbett, had previously been named and convicted for earlier offences of sexual abuse).
===Barry Bennell=== {{Split section |Barry Bennell|discuss={{TALKPAGENAME}}#Split proposed |date=July 2018}} On 16 November 2016, former Crewe defender [[Andy Woodward]] alleged in an interview with [[Daniel Taylor (journalist)|Daniel Taylor]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' newspaper that he had been the victim of [[child sexual abuse]] by former football coach Barry Bennell at the club in the 1980s<ref name="Guardian-16Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Andy Woodward: ‘It was the softer, weaker boys he targeted’|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/16/andy-woodward|accessdate=19 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=16 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="Guardian-17Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|last2=James|first2=Stuart|title=Associate of Barry Bennell also preyed on boys, two former footballers reveal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/17/barry-bennell-two-former-players-reveal|accessdate=19 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=17 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="BBC-17/11/2016">{{cite news|title=Former footballer Andy Woodward tells of sexual abuse|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-38007412|accessdate=19 November 2016|work=BBC News|date=17 November 2016}}</ref> (Woodward later claimed "People should know I suffered more than one abuser").<ref name="BBCWoodward-22Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Andy Woodward says police interview delay over abuse claims is 'shocking'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38399324|accessdate=22 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=21 December 2016}}</ref> By 21 November, it was reported that six other people had contacted the police.<ref name="Taylor-21Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Six come forward after Andy Woodward’s allegations of abuse at Crewe|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/21/crewe-alexandra-andy-woodward|accessdate=21 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=21 November 2016}}</ref>
On 22 November, ''The Guardian'' alleged that Crewe teammate [[Steve Walters (footballer)|Steve Walters]] had been another of Bennell's victims,<ref name="Taylor-22Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Second footballer reveals abuse by serial paedophile Barry Bennell|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/22/steve-walters-andy-woodward-crewe-alexandra|accessdate=22 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=22 November 2016}}</ref> while Woodward criticised Crewe for failing to apologise.<ref name="Taylor-22Nov2016Apol">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Andy Woodward criticises Crewe over lack of apology in Barry Bennell case|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/22/andy-woodward-crewe-alexandra|accessdate=23 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=22 November 2016}}</ref> On 24 November, [[Dario Gradi]], manager at Crewe during the early 1980s, released a statement saying he knew nothing of Bennell's crimes until Bennell was arrested in the United States in 1994.<ref name="Gradi-24Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Crewe Alex director of football Dario Gradi: Statement|url=http://www.crewechronicle.co.uk/sport/crewe-alex-director-football-dario-12225031|accessdate=24 November 2016|work=Crewe Chronicle|date=24 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="Independent-24Nov2016" />
On 23 November, former Manchester City players [[David White (English footballer)|David White]] and [[Paul Stewart (footballer, born 1964)|Paul Stewart]] made similar sex abuse allegations about Bennell,<ref name="BBC-23Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Football sex abuse claims: David White latest ex-player to come forward|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38084213|accessdate=24 November 2016|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|date=23 November 2016}}</ref> and about another coach<ref>{{cite news|title=Paul Stewart: I was sexually abused by my football coach for four years|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/22/paul-stewart-sexual-abuse-coach|website=The Guardian|accessdate=23 November 2016}}</ref> (later named as Frank Roper) at the Nova feeder club.<ref name="Roper-01Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Former youth footballer says abuser's death has cheated justice|url=http://www.football.co.uk/manchester-united/former-youth-footballer-says-abusers-death-has-cheated-just/8091435/#egDMLFUxpiOb8q2q.97|accessdate=2 December 2016|work=Football.co.uk|date=1 December 2016}}</ref> [[Cheshire Constabulary|Cheshire police]] said they had been contacted by 11 people (including Walters, but excluding White and Stewart) regarding the Bennell case.<ref name="BBC-25Nov2016" /> On 25 November, two further youth players, Jason Dunford<ref name="Dunford-25Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Dunford|first1=Jason|title=Football abuse: ‘I fought off Barry Bennell. Then he tried to destroy me’|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/25/child-abuse-in-football|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=25 November 2016}}</ref> and Chris Unsworth, also alleged sexual abuse by Bennell, initially at a Manchester City nursery team;<ref name="Cacciottolo-25Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Cacciottolo|first1=Mario|title=Football sex abuse claims: Two more ex-players speak out|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38093421|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=25 November 2016}}</ref> Dunford also later spoke of abuse by Frank Roper.<ref name="Roper-01Dec2016"/> (In February 2018, it was revealed that three former Manchester City players had lodged civil cases against the club in March 2016 after allegedly becoming victims of Bennell.)<ref name="Keeling-07Feb2018">{{cite news|last1=Keeling|first1=Neal|title=Three Manchester City players taking legal action in wake of Barry Bennell child sex abuse case|url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/three-manchester-city-players-taking-14260452|accessdate=8 February 2018|work=Manchester Evening News|date=7 February 2018}}</ref>
On 27 November, another former Crewe player, [[Anthony Hughes (footballer)|Anthony Hughes]], said that he too had been abused by Bennell.<ref name="BBC-27Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Football sex abuse: Crewe launch child abuse investigation|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38118429|accessdate=27 November 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=27 November 2016}}</ref> Wales and [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] youth player Matthew Monaghan,<ref name="BBCWales-01Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Matthew Monaghan 'quit football after abuse by coach'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-38164314|accessdate=6 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=1 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="Ashenden-29Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Ashenden|first1=Mark|title=Probe into abuse claims widens as more footballers reveal experiences with coach Barry Bennell|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/10676592/probe-into-abuse-claims-widens-as-more-footballers-reveal-experiences-with-coach-barry-bennell|accessdate=6 December 2016|work=Sky Sports|date=29 November 2016}}</ref> former [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] reserve team player David Lean,<ref name="Ashenden-29Nov2016" /><ref name="Kelso-29Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Kelso|first1=Paul|title=Barry Bennell victim David Lean told police of hundreds more but 'no one listened'|url=https://news.sky.com/story/barry-bennell-victim-david-lean-told-police-but-no-one-listened-10676263|accessdate=6 December 2016|work=Sky News|date=29 November 2016}}</ref> and Wimbledon and ex Northern Ireland international [[Mark Williams (footballer, born 1970)|Mark Williams]] also alleged abuse by Bennell.<ref name="Parveen-29Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Parveen|first1=Nazia|title=Former Northern Ireland player Mark Williams was ‘victim of sexual abuse’|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/29/northern-ireland-player-mark-williams-victim-sexual-abuse-barry-bennell|accessdate=6 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=29 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="Austin-29Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Austin|first1=Jack|title=Football abuse scandal: Former Premier League player becomes fifth footballer to reveal sexual abuse|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/football-abuse-scandal-former-premier-league-fifth-footballer-sexual-abuse-barry-bennell-a7445976.html|accessdate=6 December 2016|work=Independent|date=29 November 2016}}</ref>
Doubt regarding Crewe's claims of ignorance began to emerge on 25 November. First, Hamilton Smith, a director at Crewe Alexandra from 1986 to 1990, told ''[[The Guardian]]'' that the club heard an allegation that Bennell had sexually abused a junior footballer. However, Bennell was allowed to stay at the club – despite the then chairman, Norman Rowlinson, recommending that the club "get him out" and raising concerns with Manchester City – so long as Bennell was not left alone with boys and was stopped from arranging overnight stays;<ref name="Board-25Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Crewe were warned about Barry Bennell but he stayed on, says former board member|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/25/crewe-barry-bennell-former-board-member|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=25 November 2016}}</ref> it was later (February 2018) reported that Rowlinson had sought police advice about Bennell and had been advised to "move him on".<ref name="Taylor-27Feb2018">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Crewe ignored police advice in late 1980s to ‘move on’ Barry Bennell|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/27/crewe-ignored-police-advice-to-move-on-barry-bennell|accessdate=1 March 2018|work=Guardian|date=27 February 2018}}</ref> Smith said fellow directors did not want to rely on [[hearsay]] evidence and local gossip. In 2001 Smith met Tony Pickerin, the [[The Football Association|Football Association]]'s head of education and child protection (formerly head of the FA's national school at [[Lilleshall Hall#Sports centre|Lilleshall]]), and requested an FA investigation into the care of children at Gresty Road. He said he later received a three-line letter from Pickerin saying the FA had “investigated the issues and is satisfied that there is no case to answer.”<ref name="Board-25Nov2016" />
Secondly, on 7 December 2016, the BBC reported that the mother of a former Crewe youth team player wrote an anonymous letter to Dario Gradi in 1989–90, asking him to investigate "inappropriate" behaviour whereby a member of staff "took lots of boys into his room overnight" during a weekend away in Blackpool.<ref name="Ray-07Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Ray|first1=Louis Lee|title=Football abuse claims: Ex-QPR player speaks out|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38225215|accessdate=7 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=7 December 2016}}</ref>
====Bennell history==== Once a youth player at Chelsea,<ref name="Mendick-30Nov2016-Bennell">{{cite news|last1=Mendick|first1=Robert|title=Chelsea chief scout accused of child sex abuse once trained Barry Bennell, it emerges|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/11/30/chelsea-chief-scout-accused-child-sex-abuse-trained-barry-bennell/|accessdate=23 December 2016|work=The Telegraph|date=30 November 2016}}</ref> Bennell had worked for at least four English professional clubs: Manchester City, Crewe (from around 1984 until he was sacked in 1992 for reasons that have never been made public), [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] and [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]],<ref name="Herbert-25Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Herbert|first1=Ian|title=Barry Bennell: Convicted paedophile worked with at least four professional clubs|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/barry-bennell-sexual-abuse-scandal-manchester-city-leeds-stoke-crewe-a7437541.html|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=The Independent|date=25 November 2016}}</ref> and from 1992 to 1994 was head coach of the Staffordshire side [[Stone Dominoes F.C.|Stone Dominoes]].<ref name="TaylorObs-26Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=When I started talking to Barry Bennell’s victims, I had no idea how deep abuse ran in football|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/26/barry-bennell-victims-football-paedophile-interviews|accessdate=27 November 2016|work=The Observer|date=26 November 2016}}</ref> During a 1994 Dominoes tour to the United States, a 13-year-old club player claimed that Bennell had sexually abused him. Bennell was arrested in [[Jacksonville, Florida]], and eventually charged on six counts of sexual battery and [[Lascivious behavior|lewd and lascivious behavior]]. He pleaded guilty and was sentenced to four years' imprisonment.<ref name="Herbert-25Nov2016" />
In the meantime, in 1996, a UK [[Channel 4]] ''[[Dispatches (TV series)|Dispatches]]'' programme highlighted child abuse allegations involving Bennell (also other coaches: Keith Ketley in Ipswich, Bob Higgins in Hampshire). The documentary featured Ian Ackley, a former player at Derbyshire youth side White Knowl, who was one of four boys who had come forward to British police after Bennell's US arrest.<ref name="Cooper-Jan1997">{{cite news|last1=Cooper|first1=Glenda|title=Boy soccer players being put at risk|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/boy-soccer-players-being-put-at-risk-1284592.html|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=The Independent|date=23 January 1997}}</ref><ref name="Dickinson-25Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Dickinson|first1=Matt|title=‘Coach’s abuse was like a taboo, a dirty secret’|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/sport/it-was-like-a-taboo-a-dirty-secret-xhvhpcm96|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=The Times|date=25 November 2016}}</ref> As a result, although Bennell did not serve the full term of imprisonment in America, he was arrested again on his return to England.<ref name="Herbert-25Nov2016" />
In February 1998, Bennell appeared at [[Mold, Flintshire|Mold]] Crown Court in north Wales and pleaded not guilty to charges of [[indecent assault]], [[buggery]] and attempted buggery dating back to the 1970s and 1980s through to 1992, against children aged between nine and 15, with offences alleged to have taken place in Derbyshire, in the Crewe area and at [[Butlins#Pwllheli|Butlin's]] in [[Pwllheli]], north Wales. Bennell was remanded in custody to appear at [[Chester]] Crown Court in June 1998.<ref name="Warrington-25Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Former soccer coach denies child sex charges|url=http://www.warringtonguardian.co.uk/news/5315416.FORMER_SOCCER_COACH_DENIES_SEX_CHARGES/?ref=arc|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=Warrington Guardian|date=26 February 1998}}</ref> At Chester, Bennell was found guilty of 23 offences against six boys (including Ian Ackley),<ref name="Ackley-24Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Abuse victim: FA and football clubs should have protected me from monster|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2016-11-24/abuse-victim-fa-and-football-clubs-should-have-protected-me-from-monster/|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=ITV News|publisher=ITV|date=24 November 2016}}</ref> and received a nine-year jail sentence (a further 22 offences were left on file because the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] decided it was better not to put young boys through the trauma of a trial).<ref name="TaylorObs-26Nov2016" /> In May 2015, Bennell (then calling himself 'Richard Jones' and living in [[Milton Keynes]]) received a further sentence of two years after pleading guilty to sexually abusing David Lean<ref name="Ashenden-29Nov2016" /><ref name="Kelso-29Nov2016" /> at a camp in [[Macclesfield]] in 1980.<ref name="Independent-24Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Dario Gradi issues statement to say he knew nothing about Barry Bennell's abuse of young footballers before arrest|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/dario-gradi-statement-barry-bennell-sexual-abuse-crewe-alexandra-andy-woodward-steve-walters-david-a7436821.html|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=The Independent|date=24 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="Hilton-11May2015">{{cite news|last1=Hilton|first1=Rhiannon|title=Former Crewe Alex coach sentenced for child sex abuse|url=http://www.crewechronicle.co.uk/news/former-crewe-alex-coach-sentenced-9235124|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=Crewe Chronicle|date=11 May 2015}}</ref><ref name="Sentinel-12May 2016">{{cite news|title=Former Crewe Alexandra football scout jailed for indecent assault on 12-year-old child|url=http://www.stokesentinel.co.uk/crewe-alexandra-football-scout-jailed-indecent/story-26485463-detail/story.html|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=The Sentinel|date=12 May 2015}}</ref>
At the inquest in 2012 into the death of [[Gary Speed]], it was alleged that Speed and former Manchester United player [[Alan Davies (footballer)|Alan Davies]] had been "favourites" of Bennell, though there was no suggestion they had been abused by Bennell.<ref name="Ward-13May 2012">{{cite news|last1=Ward|first1=Victoria|title=Gary Speed was 'coached by paedophile' as a child|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/news/9262754/Gary-Speed-was-coached-by-paedophile-as-a-child.html|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=13 May 2012}}</ref> Both players later took their own lives, as did Mark Hazeldine, coached by Bennell at Manchester City in the early 1980s.<ref name="Taylor-16Feb2018">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Did this special football talent kill himself because of Barry Bennell?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/16/barry-bennell-manchester-city-mark-hazeldine-killed-himself|accessdate=16 February 2018|work=Guardian|date=16 February 2018}}</ref><ref name="LT-15Feb2018">{{cite news|title=Gary Speed and three others linked to Bennell committed suicide, jurors told|url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/15997114.Gary_Speed_and_three_others_linked_to_Bennell_committed_suicide__jurors_told/|accessdate=16 February 2018|work=Lancashire Telegraph|date=15 February 2018}}</ref>
====2016 and 2017 charges==== In November 2016, [[Thames Valley Police]] visited Bennell's Milton Keynes address,<ref name="BBC-25Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Football sex abuse claims: What's happened so far?|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38090926|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=BBC News|agency=BBC|date=25 November 2016}}</ref> though they said this was "in response to a safeguarding concern" and it was not investigating any offences.<ref name="BBCMore-25Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Football sex abuse claims: More former players speak out|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38093421|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=25 November 2016}}</ref> Bennell was taken to hospital in [[Stevenage]] after being found unconscious in [[Knebworth Park]] on Friday 25 November; Thames Valley police said officers had been called to a “fear for welfare” incident. It was believed Bennell was staying at a hotel after leaving his Milton Keynes home as the scandal broke.<ref name="Morris-28Nov2016" /> On 29 November 2016, then 62-year-old Bennell was charged with eight counts of sexual assault against a boy aged under 14, alleged to have taken place between 1981 and 1985.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38150244|title=Barry Bennell charged with child sex offences|date=29 November 2016|work=BBC News|accessdate=29 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="Dodd-29Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Dodd|first1=Vikram|title=Ex-football coach Barry Bennell charged with eight sexual assault offences|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/nov/29/ex-football-coach-barry-bennell-charged-with-eight-sexual-assault-offences|accessdate=30 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=29 November 2016}}</ref> Bennell appeared by [[Videotelephony|videolink]] at South Cheshire magistrates' court in Crewe on 14 December, and was remanded in custody to appear at Chester Crown Court in January 2017.<ref name="Bennell mags ct - 14Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Coach Bennell remanded on sex charges|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38314415|accessdate=14 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=14 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="Taylor - Bennellremand - 14Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Former football coach Barry Bennell remanded on child sex charges|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/dec/14/former-football-coach-barry-bennell-remanded-child-sex-charges|accessdate=14 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=14 December 2016}}</ref> On 16 January 2017, speaking via videolink from [[HM Prison Woodhill]], Bennell pleaded not guilty to the charges, and was remanded in custody until 20 March 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kemble|first1=Harry|title=BREAKING: Footie coach Barry Bennell pleads NOT GUILTY to child sex offences|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/latest-news/578890/Barry-Bennell-plea-Crewe-Alexandra-football-child-sex-offences|accessdate=16 January 2017|work=Dailystar.co.uk|date=16 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ex-football coach Barry Bennell denies sex assault charges|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-38634794|accessdate=16 January 2017|work=BBC News|date=16 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Football coach Barry Bennell denies child abuse charges|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/01/16/football-coach-barry-bennell-denies-child-abuse-charges/|accessdate=16 January 2017|work=The Telegraph}}</ref>
On 7 March 2017, Bennell was charged with eight further counts of child sexual abuse.<ref name="PA-7March2017">{{cite news|last1=Press Association|title=Barry Bennell charged with eight further counts of non-recent child sexual abuse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/mar/07/barry-bennell-charged-eight-further-counts-child-sex-abuse|accessdate=9 March 2017|work=The Guardian|date=7 March 2017}}</ref> He appeared at South Cheshire magistrates' court via video-link on 13 March, when an additional four charges were also made, and was remanded in custody to appear at Chester Crown Court on 22 March,<ref name="BBC-13Mar2017">{{cite news|title=Ex-football coach Barry Bennell in court over sex abuse charges|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-39255084|accessdate=16 March 2017|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=13 March 2017}}</ref> when all 20 charges against him were dealt with together. At that hearing, Bennell pleaded not guilty to 14 counts of indecent assault, five counts of buggery and one count of attempted buggery. The case was adjourned to 3 July 2017 at [[Queen Elizabeth II Law Courts, Liverpool|Liverpool Crown Court]] with a trial listed for January 2018 in Liverpool.<ref name="Parveen-22Mar2017">{{cite news|last1=Parveen|first1=Nazia|title=Former football coach Barry Bennell denies 20 child sexual abuse offences|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/mar/22/former-football-coach-barry-bennell-denies-20-child-sexual-abuse-offences|accessdate=22 March 2017|work=The Guardian|date=22 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="BBC-22Mar2017">{{cite news|title=Ex-football coach Barry Bennell denies 20 sex offence charges|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-39352080|accessdate=22 March 2017|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=22 March 2017}}</ref>
In May 2017, Bennell appeared in court having been charged with a further 21 offences: 18 counts of indecent assault, two of serious sexual assault and one of attempted sexual assault, relating to four boys aged between 14 and 16, and alleged to have taken place between 1983 and 1991.<ref name="BBC-09May2017">{{cite news|title=Ex-football coach Barry Bennell charged with 21 more sex offences|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-stoke-staffordshire-39861815|accessdate=9 May 2017|work=BBC News|date=9 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="BBC-17May2017">{{cite news|title=Barry Bennell: Ex-football coach appears in court by video|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-39952596|accessdate=19 May 2017|work=BBC News|date=17 May 2017}}</ref>
In June 2017, Bennell appeared in court charged with a further 14 offences (bringing the total to 55); ten of these charges related to indecent assaults on four 11- to 14-year-olds, four for alleged buggery.<ref name="Taylor-21Jun2017">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Barry Bennell charged with 14 further counts of child sexual abuse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jun/20/barry-bennell-charged-14-further-counts-historical-sexual-abuse|accessdate=21 June 2017|work=The Guardian|date=20 June 2017}}</ref> He made court appearances on 28 June<ref name="BBC-28Jun2017">{{cite news|title=Barry Bennell: Ex-football coach in court on 14 further abuse charges|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-40434911|accessdate=28 June 2017|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=28 June 2017}}</ref> and 17 July, when he was remanded in custody ahead of a trial due to start on 8 January 2018.<ref name="Echo-21Jul2017">{{cite news|last1=Humphries|first1=Jonathan|title=Ex-football youth coach Barry Bennell to stand trial for alleged abuse of 12 boys|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/ex-football-youth-coach-barry-13366125|accessdate=24 July 2017|work=Liverpool Echo|date=21 July 2017}}</ref>
====2018 trial and conviction==== As Bennell had previously changed his name to Richard Jones, in court he was referred to as 'Mr Jones'.<ref name="LEP-08Jan2018">{{cite news|title=Ex-football coach Barry Bennell goes on trial over 'child sex abuse'|url=https://www.lep.co.uk/news/crime/ex-football-coach-barry-bennell-goes-on-trial-over-child-sex-abuse-1-8944903|accessdate=8 January 2018|work=Lancashire Post|agency=Press Association|date=8 January 2018}}</ref> At the start of his trial on 8 January 2018, he pleaded guilty to seven offences of indecent assault committed between 1981 and 1991 against three boys.<ref name="Taylor-08Jan18">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Ex-football coach Barry Bennell admits seven child sexual offences|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/jan/08/barry-bennell-the-ex-football-coach-pleads-guilty-to-child-sex-offences|accessdate=8 January 2018|work=The Guardian|date=8 January 2018}}</ref> As the prosecution presented evidence relating to the remaining 48 charges, he appeared via video-link due to an illness that required him to be fed through a tube.<ref name="BBC-09Jan2018">{{cite news|title=Barry Bennell: Ex-coach had 'unfettered access' to boys|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-42623499|accessdate=10 January 2018|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=9
