January 2018}}</ref> The jury was sent out to consider its verdict on 8 February 2018, having been directed to return not guilty verdicts in respect of three indecent assault charges where no evidence had been offered.<ref name="Sky-08Feb2018">{{cite news|title=Jury to consider verdict in Barry Bennell case|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/11241063/jury-to-consider-verdict-in-barry-bennell-case|accessdate=8 February 2018|work=Sky News|date=8 February 2018}}</ref> On 13 February 2018, Bennell was found guilty of 36 sex offences;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-43050466|title=Ex-football coach Barry Bennell guilty of sex abuse|publisher=BBC News|date=13 February 2018}}</ref><ref name="Taylor-13Feb2018">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Barry Bennell found guilty of sexually abusing youth footballers|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/13/barry-bennell-found-guilty-of-sexually-abusing-youth-footballers|accessdate=13 February 2018|work=Guardian|date=13 February 2018}}</ref> after the jury were given more time to consider other counts, on 15 February he was convicted of seven further offences. Following the earlier seven guilty pleas, he was sentenced on Monday 19 February for a total of 50 offences against 12 boys,<ref name="BBC-15Feb2018">{{cite news|title=Ex-football coach Barry Bennell guilty of further sex abuse|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-43069415|accessdate=15 February 2018|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=15 February 2018}}</ref> and was jailed for 31 years (being expected to serve half in custody, with the rest on licence).<ref name="BBC-19Feb2018">{{cite news|title='Devil incarnate' Barry Bennell sentenced to 31 years|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-43118069|accessdate=19 February 2018|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=19 February 2018}}</ref><ref name="Taylor-19Feb2018">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Barry Bennell branded ‘sheer evil’ as he is sentenced to 31 years|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/19/barry-bennell-branded-sheer-evil-as-he-is-sentenced-to-31-years|accessdate=19 February 2018|work=Guardian|date=19 February 2018}}</ref>
After the guilty verdicts, victims Andy Woodward, Micky Fallon, Chris Unsworth and Steve Walters read statements outside Liverpool Crown Court;<ref name="BBC-15Feb2018"/><ref name="Gstaff-15Feb2018">{{cite news|last1=Guardian staff|title='We are no longer afraid of you': Barry Bennell's victims speak out|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/15/barry-bennell-victims-speak-outside-liverpool-crown-court|accessdate=15 February 2018|work=Guardian|date=15 February 2018}}</ref> another victim, Gary Cliffe, waived his anonymity to speak about the abuse he had experienced, aged 11 to 15, from Bennell while at Manchester City.<ref name="Taylor-15Feb2018">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Manchester City ‘ignored warnings’ and kept Barry Bennell in youth set-up|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/15/manchester-city-barry-bennell-warning|accessdate=15 February 2018|work=Guardian|date=15 February 2018}}</ref> The club offered its "heartfelt sympathy to all victims for the unimaginably traumatic experiences they have endured", and said an internal review had identified serious allegations of child sex abuse in respect of a second man, John Broome<ref name="BBC-Broome-15Feb2018">{{cite news|title=Manchester City name second man linked with sexual abuse|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-manchester-43076203|accessdate=16 February 2018|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=15 February 2018}}</ref> (now dead), with "potential historic connections to the club".<ref name="BBC-15Feb2018"/> Crewe Alexandra expressed its "deepest sympathies" to Bennell's victims, saying it was not aware of any sexual abuse by Bennell nor had it received any complaint about sexual abuse by him before or during his employment with the club.<ref name="BBC-15Feb2018"/> This claim has been disputed: the ''Guardian'' alleged Bennell had to leave Crewe following a complaint against him, having been identified as a risk long before joining Crewe, amid a cover-up at Manchester City.<ref name="Taylor-15Feb2018"/> [[Alex Carlile, Baron Carlile of Berriew|Lord Carlile]], the barrister who prosecuted Bennell in 1998, accused Crewe of 'brushing the scandal under the carpet'.<ref name="Roan-15Feb2018">{{cite news|last1=Roan|first1=Dan|title=Barry Bennell: Crewe 'brushed scandal under carpet' says Lord Carlile|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38632026|accessdate=16 February 2018|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=15 February 2018}}</ref>
Following complaints from other former players (the ''Guardian'' said there had allegations from another 86 former footballers),<ref name="Taylor-100s-15Feb2018">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title='There will be hundreds more,' says player Bennell abused on Maine Road pitch|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/15/barry-bennell-gary-cliffe-manchester-city|accessdate=15 February 2018|work=Guardian|date=15 February 2018}}</ref> mostly from Manchester City and Crewe, Bennell was reported to be likely to face a further trial,<ref name="Taylor-15Feb2018"/> though the judge (Clement Goldstone QC) said the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] would have to think carefully as Bennell "may well die in prison."<ref name="Taylor-19Feb2018" /> In September 2018, it was reported that the police and Crown Prosecution Service regarded some of allegations, particularly the rape of minors, as serious enough to warrant criminal action, potentially in 2019.<ref name="Taylor-6Sep2018">{{cite news |last1=Taylor |first1=Daniel |title=Jailed football coach Barry Bennell may face further abuse charges |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/sep/06/jailed-football-coach-barry-bennell-may-face-further-abuse-charges |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=Guardian |date=6 September 2018}}</ref>
In April 2018, it was reported that Bennell was appealing against his 30-year sentence.<ref name="Taylor-10Apr2018">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Barry Bennell appeals against 30-year prison sentence for sexual offences|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/apr/10/barry-bennell-appeal-against-30-year-sentence|accessdate=10 April 2018|work=The Guardian|date=10 April 2018}}</ref> In June 2018, his appeal was rejected and the sentence was upheld by three judges at the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] in London.<ref name="Quinn-20Jun2018">{{cite news |last1=Quinn |first1=Ben |title=Barry Bennell victims welcome rejection of appeal against jail term |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/jun/20/barry-bennell-victims-welcome-rejection-of-appeal-against-jail-term |accessdate=21 June 2018 |work=Guardian |date=20 June 2018}}</ref>
===George Ormond=== On 24 November 2016, ''The Guardian'' reported that an anonymous ex-footballer had contacted police to say he was a victim of George Ormond,<ref name="Taylor-24Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Former Newcastle United player tells police he was abused in club’s youth system|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/24/george-ormond|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=24 November 2016}}</ref> a former Newcastle United youth coach who was jailed in December 2002 for offences against young footballers in the area.<ref name="Telegraph-16Dec2002">{{cite news|title=Football coach gets six years for abusing boys|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1416292/Football-coach-gets-six-years-for-abusing-boys.html|accessdate=28 November 2016|work=The Telegraph|date=16 December 2002}}</ref> On 29 November 2016, ''The Guardian'' reported allegations by [[Derek Bell (footballer, born 1963)|Derek Bell]] that he had been abused by George Ormond at the Montagu and [[Blakelaw and North Fenham|North Fenham]] boys football club in the 1970s.<ref name="Conn-29Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Conn|first1=David|title=Former Newcastle player on being abused: ‘It was horrific. He thought it was normal’|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/29/derek-bell-abuse-coach|accessdate=29 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=29 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="Conn/Parveen-06Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Conn|first1=David|last2=Parveen|first2=Nazia|title=‘The culture was seedy’: the boys club at the heart of north-east football abuse scandal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/06/montagu-and-north-fenham-boys-club|accessdate=6 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=6 December 2016}}</ref> Bell later played for Newcastle United (1980–1984) and on 1 December accused Newcastle of a cover-up over the abuse allegations.<ref name="Conn-Bellcoverup-1Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Conn|first1=David|title=Newcastle United accused of a cover-up in 1990s by sex abuse victim Derek Bell|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/01/newcastle-accused-cover-up-1990s-abuse|accessdate=1 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=1 December 2016}}</ref> Bell claimed he alerted the club in 1998 but although Ormond's employment ended, his conduct was not investigated or reported to the police until 2001.<ref name="Conn-Bellcoverup-1Dec2016" /> ''The Guardian'' also reported allegations about Ormond from David Eatock, who signed for Newcastle as an 18-year-old in 1995.<ref name="Eatock-30Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Former Newcastle player David Eatock on being abused: ‘I wanted to cry but I couldn’t even cry’|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/30/david-eatock-abuse-newcastle-united|accessdate=1 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=30 November 2016}}</ref>
Ormond was described by a judge in 2002 as a "predatory abuser" after he was convicted of 12 indecent assaults and one attempted indecent assault on seven boys which had taken place between 1975 and 1999.<ref name="Telegraph-16Dec2002" />
====2017 charges==== In May 2017, Ormond, aged 61 and from [[Newton Abbot]] in Devon, was charged with 29 offences (27 of indecent assault, one charge of indecency with a child and one of buggery, relating to 17 male complainants and alleged to have taken place from 1973 to 1998).<ref name="Taylor-19May2017">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Former football coach George Ormond charged with 29 counts of child sexual abuse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/may/19/football-coach-george-ormond-charged-child-sexual-abuse-newcastle|accessdate=20 May 2017|work=The Guardian|date=19 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="BBC-19May2017">{{cite news|title=Ex-Newcastle youth coach George Ormond faces sex charges|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-39976788|accessdate=20 May 2017|work=BBC News|date=19 May 2017}}</ref> He appeared by videolink at Newcastle magistrates' court on 9 June, and was bailed to appear on 7 July 2017 at Newcastle Crown Court.<ref name="Conn-09Jun2017">{{cite news|last1=Conn|first1=David|title=George Ormond in court charged with 29 counts of child sexual abuse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jun/09/george-ormond-court-newcastle|accessdate=11 June 2017|work=The Guardian|date=9 June 2017}}</ref> In that appearance, he denied 35 historic sexual offences (33 of indecent assault, one of gross indecency with a child and a serious sexual offence with a 15-year-old) said to relate to 18 complainants, and was bailed to reappear in May 2018.<ref name="Echo-07Jul2017">{{cite news|last1=Wilkinson|first1=Tom|title=Former Newcastle United coach George Ormond denies 35 historic sex offences|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/15397399.Former_Newcastle_United_coach_denies_35_historic_sex_offences/|accessdate=14 July 2017|work=Northern Echo|agency=PA|date=7 July 2017}}</ref>
====2018 trial and conviction==== Ormond's trial at Newcastle Crown Court started on 24 May 2018. He was charged with 38 sexual offences against 19 victims over a 25-year period from 1973 to 1998. This includes the time he worked at Newcastle United, at a north-east boys’ football club, and as a helper on the [[The Duke of Edinburgh's Award|Duke of Edinburgh's Award scheme]] at a Newcastle school.<ref name="Conn-24May2018">{{cite news|last1=Conn|first1=David|title=Coach watched porn with Newcastle United youth players, court hears|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/may/24/george-ormond-newcastle-united-coach-sexual-abuse-trial|accessdate=28 May 2018|work=Guardian|date=24 May 2018}}</ref> The prosecution case concluded on 25 June; Ormond elected not to give evidence in the trial,<ref name="Conn-25Jun2018">{{cite news |last1=Conn |first1=David |title=George Ormond was ‘classic groomer and manipulator’, jury told |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/jun/25/george-ormond-trial-football-newcastle-united-youth-team |accessdate=26 June 2018 |work=Guardian |date=25 June 2018}}</ref> and, after the judge's summing up, the jury retired to consider its verdicts on 29 June.<ref name="Nichol-29Jun2018">{{cite news |last1=Nichol |first1=Sara |title=George Ormond football sex abuse trial: Jury retires to consider verdict |url=https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/george-ormond-newcastle-trial-jury-14844803 |accessdate=2 July 2018 |work=ChronicleLive |date=29 June 2018}}</ref> On 3 July 2018, the jury returned guilty verdicts on 36 counts of sexual abuse against 18 victims over a 24-year period between 1973 and 1997 (he was acquitted of two other offences);<ref name="Conn-3Jul2018">{{cite news |last1=Conn |first1=David |title=Football coach George Ormond found guilty of sexually abusing 18 boys |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/jul/03/coach-george-ormond-found-guilty-of-sexually-abusing-18-boys |accessdate=3 July 2018 |work=Guardian |date=3 July 2018}}</ref> the following day, Ormond was sentenced to 20 years in prison.<ref name="BBC-4Jul2018">{{cite news |title=Youth coach George Ormond jailed for sexually abusing boys |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-tyne-44708149 |accessdate=5 July 2018 |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=4 July 2018}}</ref>
Newcastle United made no comment apart from saying it had cooperated with the police and FA inquiries.<ref name="Conn-3Jul2018"/> Two victims of Ormond, Paul Chilton and Gary Weymes (and who both gave evidence against him), waived their right to anonymity and said Ormond's 20-year sentence was "not enough" while suggesting other victims had yet to come forward.<ref name="BBC-10Jul2018">{{cite news |title=George Ormond sex abuse victim: 'To me he was God' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-tyne-44769509 |accessdate=10 July 2018 |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC}}</ref>
===Eddie Heath=== On 29 November 2016, [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] announced it was investigating allegations of historical sexual abuse in the 1970s, including a secret payment to a former player who had accused the club’s ex-chief scout Eddie Heath of child sexual abuse.<ref name="Mendick-30Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Mendick|first1=Robert|last2=Rumsby|first2=Ben|title=Exclusive: Chelsea made secret payment to player in child sex abuse claim|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/11/29/chelsea-made-secret-payment-player-child-sex-abuse-claim/|accessdate=30 November 2016|work=Telegraph|date=30 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="Guardian-chelsea30Nov2016" /><ref name="Indie-30Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Chelsea made 'secret payment' after former chief scout Eddie Heath was accused of sexual abuse by youth player|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/chelsea-football-sexual-abuse-scandal-a7446466.html|accessdate=30 November 2016|work=The Independent|date=30 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="Olley-30Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Olley|first1=James|last2=Collomosse|first2=Tom|title=Eddie Heath: The former Chelsea scout who ‘spent a lot of time in his office, decorating and cooking meals for schoolboy players’|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/eddie-heath-the-former-chelsea-scout-who-spent-a-lot-of-time-in-his-office-decorating-and-cooking-a3408566.html|accessdate=30 November 2016|work=Evening Standard}}</ref><ref name="Fifield-30Nov2016" /> On 2 December, the former player was named as [[Gary Johnson (footballer, born 1959)|Gary Johnson]], who said he was paid £50,000 not to go public with allegations that he was sexually abused by Heath;<ref name="PA-01Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Gary Johnson says Chelsea paid him £50,000 for silence about abuse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/dec/02/gary-johnson-says-chelsea-paid-him-50000-for-silence-about-abuse|accessdate=2 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=2 December 2016}}</ref> the following day, Chelsea apologised "profusely" to Johnson,<ref name="PA-03Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Chelsea apologises 'profusely' to former player over alleged abuse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/dec/03/chelsea-apologises-profusely-to-former-player-abused-while-at-club|accessdate=3 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=3 December 2016}}</ref> who later demanded further financial compensation from the club.<ref name="Johnsoncomp-08Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Gary Johnson demands compensation from Chelsea over sexual abuse claims|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/08/gary-johnson-demands-further-compensation-from-chelsea-over-sexual-abuse-claims-eddie-heath|accessdate=8 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=8 December 2016}}</ref> Also on 3 December, ''[[The Independent]]'' reported an allegation from another Chelsea youth player that [[Dario Gradi]], then Chelsea's assistant manager, visited the player's family's home to "smooth over" a complaint of sexual assault against Heath in 1974;<ref name="Indie-03Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Herbert|first1=Ian|last2=Williams|first2=Richard A L|last3=Pitt-Brooke|first3=Jack|title=Dario Gradi covered up sex abuse complaint, ex-Chelsea youth player claims|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/dario-gradi-chelsea-sex-abuse-youth-player-complaint-crewe-alexandra-smoothed-over-claims-a7453151.html|accessdate=3 December 2016|work=The Independent|date=3 December 2016}}</ref> Gradi was among the first to be targeted by the FA's enquiry,<ref name="FAGradi-06Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=FA to question Dario Gradi over claims he ‘smoothed over’ sex abuse at Chelsea|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/06/fa-dario-gradi-chelsea|accessdate=6 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=6 December 2016}}</ref> and, in connection with these allegations, on 11 December 2016, the FA announced that it had suspended Gradi<ref name="FAGradi-11Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Dario Gradi suspended by FA pending investigation into sexual abuse scandal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/11/dario-gradi-suspended-fa-sexual-abuse-scandal|accessdate=11 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=11 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="BBC-FA-Gradi-11Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Dario Gradi: Crewe Alexandra director suspended pending FA investigation|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38279170|accessdate=11 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=11 December 2016}}</ref> (Gradi subsequently said he had been notified by the FA of his interim suspension from football on 25 November, and reiterated "that I will do everything within my power to assist all investigatory authorities").<ref name="Ryan-12Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Ryan|first1=Belinda|title=Dario Gradi issues statement about his suspension by FA|url=http://www.crewechronicle.co.uk/news/dario-gradi-issues-statement-suspension-12309369|accessdate=12 December 2016|work=Crewe Chronicle|date=12 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="Rawlinson-12Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Rawlinson|first1=Kevin|title=Dario Gradi offers to help in football child abuse investigation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/12/dario-gradi-offers-to-help-in-football-child-abuse-investigation|accessdate=12 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=12 December 2016}}</ref> Former Chelsea youth goalkeeper [[Derek Richardson (footballer)|Derek Richardson]] became the third player to allege abuse by Heath.<ref name="Mendick-02Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Mendick|first1=Robert|last2=Rumsby|first2=Ben|title=Former FA chief approved 'gag' on Chelsea abuse victim|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/12/02/former-fa-chief-approved-gag-chelsea-abuse-victim/|accessdate=3 December 2016|work=Telegraph|date=2 December 2016}}</ref>
On 4 December 2016, Heath was the subject of allegations of early 1980s abuse made by former youth player Russell Davy, at another London club, [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]];<ref name="ITV-04Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Charlton Athletic FC launches internal investigation over allegation of historical sexual abuse of formeryouth player|url=http://www.itv.com/news/london/2016-12-04/charlton-athletic-fc-launches-internal-investigation-over-allegation-of-historical-sexual-abuse-of-former-youth-player/|accessdate=4 December 2016|work=ITV|publisher=ITV|date=4 December 2016}}</ref> Davy also wrote to the FA about Heath but his letter was not even acknowledged.<ref name="Conn re Brackenridge-29Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Conn|first1=David|title=Child abuse in sport and the progress made towards eradicating it|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/29/fa-child-protection-work-celia-brackenridge|accessdate=30 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=29 December 2016}}</ref> Later the same month, another Charlton youth player Paul Collins also alleged abuse by Heath.<ref name="BBC-Collins-19Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Football abuse victim: Telling mum 'broke her heart'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38370789|accessdate=23 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=19 December 2016}}</ref>
In the 1950s and 1960s, Heath was employed at [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] (former goalkeeper Peter Chapman described him as "the dark eminence of Orient's youth outfit"),<ref name="Chapman">{{cite book|last1=Chapman|first1=Peter|title=Out of Time: 1966 and the End of Old-Fashioned Britain|date=2016|publisher=Bloomsbury|isbn=9781472917164}}</ref> where his sexual abuse was common knowledge among players including former captain Jimmy Scott,<ref name="Leyton-2Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Collomosse|first1=Tom|title=Leyton Orient squad knew Eddie Heath was sexually abusing youth players before move to Chelsea, claims former player|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/leyton-orient-squad-knew-eddie-heath-was-sexually-abusing-youth-players-before-move-to-chelsea-a3410851.html|accessdate=23 December 2016|work=Evening Standard|date=2 December 2016}}</ref> before joining Chelsea.<ref name="Olley-30Nov2016" /> In 1979, he contested his dismissal from Chelsea by then manager [[Geoff Hurst]] at an industrial tribunal.<ref name="Olley-30Nov2016" /> After leaving Chelsea, he worked at [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] and then Charlton Athletic, before dying of a heart attack in the early 1980s.<ref name="Mendick-30Nov2016-Bennell" />
===Bob Higgins=== At [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], former trainees Dean Radford, Jamie Webb and, later, Billy Seymour told the BBC about incidents they said happened when they were in their teens.<ref name="Vardy-1Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Vardy|first1=Emma|title=Ex-Southampton footballers describe abuse at club|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-38128841|accessdate=2 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=1 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="BBC-QPR-06Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Ex-QPR employee Chris Gieler named in abuse inquiry|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38221613|accessdate=6 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=6 December 2016}}</ref> [[Matt Le Tissier]], who joined Southampton as a trainee in the mid-1980s, recalled being given a naked massage by Higgins. Le Tissier reiterated that he does not feel that he was abused, but thought this incident and other behaviour he witnessed was "very wrong".<ref>{{cite news|title=Matt Le Tissier 'given naked massage' by coach Bob Higgins|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-38230154|accessdate=4 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=6 December 2016}}</ref> By 4 December 2016, six players had alleged abuse by an ex-Southampton employee,<ref name="BBC-Soton-03Dec2016" /> and various media named him as Bob Higgins, until recently a first team coach (said not to be involved with youth players) at non-league side [[Fleet Town F.C.|Fleet Town]].<ref name="Morris-04Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Steven|title=Southampton FC trainer named in connection with abuse allegations|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/dec/04/southampton-fc-trainer-named-in-connection-with-abuse-allegations|accessdate=4 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=4 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="BBCHiggins-04Dec2016"/><ref name="Evans-04Dec2016" />
Bob Higgins was dismissed by Southampton in 1989 after several allegations were made against him,<ref name="Morris-04Dec2016" /> and after he set up the "Bob Higgins Soccer Academy", the [[English Football League|Football League]] wrote to all clubs in April 1989 warning them against any involvement with it.<ref name="James/Morris-05Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=James|first1=Stuart|last2=Morris|first2=Steven|title=Football League warned all its clubs about Bob Higgins in 1989|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/05/football-league-warned-all-its-clubs-about-bob-higgins-in-1989|accessdate=5 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=5 December 2016}}</ref> He then joined the [[Malta Football Association]].<ref name="BBC-Malta-07Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Bob Higgins: Ex-Southampton coach 'showered naked' with Malta youth players|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38244413|accessdate=7 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=7 December 2016|ref=c2016}}</ref>
In 1991 he was charged with six counts of indecent assault against young boys he had been coaching; at the trial at Southampton Crown Court, he was acquitted on the direction of the judge<ref name="BBCHiggins-04Dec2016"/> when the prosecution offered no evidence.<ref name="Morris-04Dec2016" /><ref name="Evans-04Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Evans|first1=Martin|title=Southampton coach sacked over child abuse allegations is still working in football|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/12/04/southampton-coach-sacked-child-abuse-allegations-still-working/|accessdate=5 December 2016|work=Telegraph|date=4 December 2016}}</ref> Higgins was suspended by the Malta FA between 1990 and 1992 when the original allegations were made, reinstated on a year's probation after being cleared, and then left in 1994.<ref name="BBC-Malta-07Dec2016" /> While working in Malta, Higgins was said to have 'showered naked' with young players; one youth said it was common for Higgins to drive him in his car and touch him around his neck and his legs.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=BBC|date=7 December 2016|title=Bob Higgins: Ex-Southampton coach 'showered naked' with Malta youth players|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38244413|work=BBC News|accessdate=8 December 2016}}</ref>
Higgins then worked as a youth coach at [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] from May 1995 to April 1996,<ref name="James/Morris-05Dec2016" /><ref name="Fisher-05Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Fisher|first1=Paul|title=Ex-Peterborough United youth manager Bob Higgins named by police in football abuse investigation|url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/crime/ex-peterborough-united-youth-manager-bob-higgins-named-by-police-in-football-abuse-investigation-1-7713396|accessdate=5 December 2016|work=Peterborough Telegraph|date=5 December 2016}}</ref> and was investigated as part of the 1997 Channel 4 ''Dispatches'' investigation, and denied allegations of abuse, claiming he was a [[Faith healing|faith healer]] and [[born again]] Christian.<ref name="James/Morris-05Dec2016" /> One former youth player alleged Higgins provided "soapy massages";<ref name="Morris-07Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Steven|title=Former Peterborough player expresses anger that Bob Higgins carried on coaching|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/07/former-peterborough-player-expresses-anger-that-bob-higgins-carried-on-coaching|accessdate=7 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=7 December 2016}}</ref> another, 'Jon' (not his real name), said he was left emotionally scarred and needing treatment for mental health issues, and that complaints made in 2013 to Peterborough resulted in no action.<ref name="Morris-9Feb207">{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Steven|title=Former player angry ‘nothing was done’ after alleging abuse by Bob Higgins|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/feb/09/football-youth-player-alleged-abuse-bob-higgins-peterborough|accessdate=10 February 2017|work=The Guardian|date=9 February 2017}}</ref>
In 1997, letters were sent to clubs and youth groups warning them that Higgins posed a risk to children.<ref name="BBCHiggins-04Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Ex-Southampton football coach accused of abuse 'not vetted'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38200993|accessdate=5 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC}}</ref><ref name="Evans-04Dec2016" /> Higgins was then appointed manager of non-league [[Bashley F.C.|Bashley]], until he was sacked in 2001.<ref name="Evans-04Dec2016" /> The BBC reported that Higgins then worked at [[Winchester City F.C.|Winchester City]] for a few months; "At a meeting with Hampshire County Council and the local FA, Winchester representatives were shown the TV documentary that had aired a few years earlier and it was made clear it was inappropriate for Mr Higgins to stay at the club."<ref name="BBC-06Dec2016" />
====2017 charges==== On 5 July 2017, Higgins was charged with 65 counts of indecent assault. The offences were alleged to have taken place in the 1980s and 1990s and to have involved 23 alleged victims.<ref name="HantsConst">{{cite news|title=Man charged in connection with non-recent child abuse offences|url=https://www.hampshire.police.uk/news/general/man-charged-connection-non-recent-child-abuse-offences/|accessdate=5 July 2017|work=Hampshire Constabulary|date=5 July 2017}}</ref><ref name="Taylor-5Jul2017">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Bob Higgins, former Southampton coach, charged with 65 counts of child sexual abuse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jul/05/bob-higgins-charged-child-sexual-abuse-southampton-coach|accessdate=5 July 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 July 2017}}</ref> He appeared at West Hampshire ([[Southampton]]) Magistrates' Court on 20 July, when he indicated he would plead not guilty to the alleged offences and was given unconditional bail until a hearing at Winchester Crown Court on 16 August 2017.<ref name="BBCHants-20Jul2017">{{cite news|title=Bob Higgins: Ex-Saints coach faces child abuse charges|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-40665856|accessdate=24 July 2017|work=BBC|date=20 July 2017}}</ref><ref name="BBC-16Aug2017">{{cite news|title=Bob Higgins: Ex-Saints coach child abuse charges trial date set|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-40948033|accessdate=18 August 2017|work=BBC Hampshire and Isle of Wight|date=16 August 2017}}</ref> At a pre-trial hearing in January 2018, Higgins denied 50 charges of abusing 24 boys between 1970 and 1996; he was set to stand trial at Salisbury Crown Court on 29 May 2018.<ref name="Hammond-04Jan2018">{{cite news|last1=Hammond|first1=Clive|title=Former Saints youth coach Bob Higgins denies 50 counts on child abuse|url=http://www.dailyecho.co.uk/news/15808356.Former_Saints_youth_coach_denies_50_counts_on_child_abuse/|accessdate=9 April 2018|work=Southern Daily Echo|date=4 January 2018}}</ref>
====2018 trial==== The trial at Salisbury Crown Court started on 29 May 2018, with Higgins, 65, denying 50 counts of indecent assault between 1971 and 1996 in relation to 24 boys. The prosecution case started on 30 May,<ref name="BBC-30May2018">{{cite news |title=Bob Higgins trial: Ex-football coach 'was serial abuser' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-44300482 |accessdate=31 May 2018 |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=30 May 2018}}</ref> with the trial sheduled to last six to eight weeks.<ref name="Morris-29May2018">{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Steven|title=Bob Higgins child sexual abuse trial begins|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/may/29/bob-higgins-child-sexual-abuse-trial-begins|accessdate=29 May 2018|work=Guardian|date=29 May 2018}}</ref> The jury retired to consider their verdicts on 17 July 2018.<ref name="BBC-17Jul2018">{{cite news |title=Bob Higgins: Ex-football coach abuse trial jury retires |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-44862619 |accessdate=18 July 2018 |work=BBC News |date=17 July 2018}}</ref> On 23 July, Higgins was found guilty of one charge of indecent assault, and not guilty of another count of the same offence, while the jury failed to reach verdicts on 48 other counts of the same charge.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bob Higgins trial: Ex-football coach guilty of sex assault charge |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-44688435 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=23 July 2018 |date=23 July 2018}}</ref> A retrial is to be held in February 2019.<ref name="Sky-23Jul2018">{{cite news |title=Former Southampton coach Bob Higgins to face retrial on indecent assault charges |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/11446431/former-southampton-coach-bob-higgins-to-face-retrial-on-indecent-assault-charges |accessdate=30 July 2018 |work=Sky Sport |agency=PA Sport |date=23 July 2018}}</ref>
===Hugh Stevenson=== On 5 December 2016, allegations spread to [[Scotland]] when a former youth football coach and assistant referee, Hugh Stevenson (who died in 2004), was accused by Peter Haynes of child sex offences over a three to four-year period said to have begun on the day of the [[1979 Scottish Cup Final]] between [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] and [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] at [[Hampden Park]].<ref name="Daly-05Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Daly|first1=Mark|last2=Conaghan|first2=Martin|last3=McKay|first3=Calum|title=Child sex claims against youth coach Hugh Stevenson|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-38208329|accessdate=5 December 2016|work=BBC|publisher=BBC|date=5 December 2016}}</ref> Stevenson was assistant referee in at least four international matches, including the [[England national football team|England]] v [[Wales national football team|Wales]] home international at [[Wembley Stadium|Wembley]] in 1977, and was a club official at Eastercraigs Boys Club between the late 1970s and mid 1980s, before being asked to leave after attempting inappropriate contact with a boy at another club. He then moved to the [[Glasgow]]-based Chelsea Boys Club, which had an affiliation to the London club, and later was involved with the [[Paisley, Renfrewshire|Paisley]]-based Ferguslie United<ref name="Daly-05Dec2016" /> and [[Cowdenbeath F.C.|Cowdenbeath]].<ref name="Dalyetal-09Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Daly|first1=Mark|last2=Conaghan|first2=Martin|last3=McKay|first3=Calum|title=Youth coach Hugh Stevenson continued in football after child sex claims|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-38267236|accessdate=10 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=9 December 2016}}</ref> [[Police Scotland]] confirmed that a then 55-year-old man had been investigated by [[Strathclyde Police]] in 1993 and 1996, with reports submitted to the [[Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service]] each time.<ref name="Daly-05Dec2016" />
Also on 5 December 2016, Mitch Agnew, part of Ferguslie United's coaching set-up in the 1990s and a senior figure in the Scottish Youth Football Association, was suspended pending an investigation.<ref name="Dalyetal-09Dec2016" />
===Jim McCafferty=== In [[Belfast]], on 7 December 2016, former [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] youth coach Jim McCafferty was charged with offences relating to sexual activity with a child, allegedly committed in Northern Ireland.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ex-football coach Jim McCafferty charged with sexual activity with a child|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-38245187|accessdate=7 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=7 December 2016}}</ref> On 5 January 2017, he appeared via video-link from [[HM Prison Maghaberry|Maghaberry jail]] in County Antrim at Belfast Laganside court, charged with engaging in sexual activity with a child aged between 13 and 16 in Northern Ireland between December 2011 and December 2014. At this and a further court hearing, he was remanded in custody.<ref name="McDonald-05Jan2017">{{cite news|last1=McDonald|first1=Henry|title=Former Celtic youth coach charged over child abuse held in prison for own safety|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jan/05/former-celtic-youth-coach-child-abuse-prison-jim-mccafferty|accessdate=17 March 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="Beattie-27Jan2017">{{cite news|last1=Beattie|first1=Jilly|title=Police files handed to PPS over Celtic kit coach child sex charges|url=http://www.belfastlive.co.uk/news/belfast-news/police-files-handed-pps-over-12513395|accessdate=17 March 2017|work=Belfast Live|date=27 January 2017}}</ref> McCafferty was due to appear at Laganside on Friday 1 September,<ref name="ETimes-27Aug2017">{{cite news|title=Former Celtic coach to appear in court on sex charges|url=http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/15498018.Former_Celtic_coach_to_appear_in_court_on_sex_charges/|accessdate=29 August 2017|work=Evening Times|date=27 August 2017}}</ref> but proceedings were delayed pending medical reports.<ref name="Donnelly-16Sep2017">{{cite news|last1=Donnelly|first1=Michael|title=Trial of ex-Celtic kit man on child sex abuse charges is delayed over medical report|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/northern-ireland/trial-of-exceltic-kit-man-on-child-sex-abuse-charges-is-delayed-over-medical-report-36136125.html|accessdate=16 October 2017|work=Belfast Telegraph|date=16 September 2017}}</ref> At a further court hearing on 27 September 2017, McCafferty's intention to plead guilty to at least two of eight sex charges was considered, but the [[arraignment]] hearing was adjourned until November 2017 to allow psychiatric reports.<ref name="IrishNews-27Sep2017">{{cite news|title=Former Celtic kit man Jim McCafferty to plead guilty to child abuse pending medical reports|url=http://www.irishnews.com/news/northernirelandnews/2017/09/27/news/former-celtic-kit-man-jim-mccafferty-to-plead-guilty-to-child-abuse-pending-medical-reports-1147147/|accessdate=16 October 2017|work=The Irish News|date=27 September 2017}}</ref> In February 2018 at Belfast Crown Court, McCafferty was formally arraigned on eight charges, with a trial date set for 21 May 2018.<ref name="IR-23Feb2018">{{cite news|title=Former Celtic kit man Jim McCafferty to face trial|url=https://www.irishnews.com/news/northernirelandnews/2018/02/24/news/former-celtic-kit-man-to-face-trial-1262810/|accessdate=4 April 2018|work=Irish News|date=23 February 2018}}</ref>
McCafferty, former kitman for Celtic, Hibernian and [[Falkirk F.C.|Falkirk]], admitted abusing teenagers in the 1980s and 1990s while coaching boys’ and junior teams in [[West Lothian]], Scotland, and at Celtic between 1990 and 1996.<ref name="Kitman-07Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Former Celtic kitman Jim McCafferty ‘confesses to sexual abuse in 1990s’|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/07/celtic-kitman-jim-mccafferty-confesses-sexual-abuse-football-club-1990s|accessdate=9 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=7 December 2016}}</ref>
====2018 trial and conviction==== On 21 May 2018, McCafferty, aged 71, pleaded guilty to all eight charges at Laganside Courts in Belfast. McCafferty was remanded to Maghaberry Prison pending a sentencing hearing to take place on 22 June 2018.<ref name="Fitzmaurice-21May2018">{{cite news|last1=Fitzmaurice|first1=Maurice|title=Former Celtic coach Jim McCafferty pleads guilty to child abuse|url=https://www.belfastlive.co.uk/news/belfast-news/former-celtic-coach-jim-mccafferty-14684840|accessdate=21 May 2018|work=Belfast Live|date=21 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="BBC-21May2018">{{cite news|title=Ex-Celtic coach Jim McCafferty pleads guilty to child sex abuse|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-44194256|accessdate=21 May 2018|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=21 May 2018}}</ref> Sentencing was later adjourned to 13 August 2018<ref name="BBC-25Jun2018">{{cite news |title=Jim McCafferty: Sentencing adjourned for ex-Celtic kitman |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-44608061 |accessdate=26 June 2018 |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=25 June 2018}}</ref> when McCafferty was sentenced to three years and nine months in prison.<ref name="BBC-13Aug2018">{{cite news |title=Ex-Celtic coach McCafferty jailed for child sex abuse |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-45170358 |accessdate=17 August 2018 |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=13 August 2018}}</ref>
===Paul McCann=== On 5 January 2017, the FA suspended former youth coach Paul McCann, who worked for Crewe in a voluntary capacity in the 1980s and 90s and was assistant coach of the club's under-16s youth team for a time,<ref name="McCannsuspension-5Jan2017">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|last2=Parveen|first2=Nazia|title=Former Crewe youth coach suspended by Football Association|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jan/04/crewe-paul-mccann-suspended-fa|accessdate=5 January 2017|work=The Guardian|date=5 January 2017}}</ref> and later a volunteer youth coach at Merseyside non-league club AFC Bebington in 2014-15.<ref name="Reed-5Jan2017">{{cite news|last1=Reed|first1=Jim|last2=Ray|first2=Louise Lee|last3=Ornstein|first3=David|title=Former Crewe coach Paul McCann suspended by FA|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38508783|accessdate=5 January 2017|work=BBC News|date=5 January 2017}}</ref>
====2018 charges, trial and acquittal==== Almost a year later, on 3 January 2018, McCann, 57, appeared at South Cheshire magistrates' court charged with six non-recent sexual offences,<ref name="Cain-02Jan2018">{{cite news|last1=Cain|first1=Andrew|title=Former Crewe Alex coach charged with sexual offences|url=http://www.crewechronicle.co.uk/news/former-crewe-alex-coach-charged-14105014|accessdate=2 January 2018|work=Crewe Chronicle|date=2 January 2018}}</ref> including indecent assault on a boy under the age of 16 years and indecent assault on the same victim when aged 16 or over, dating back to 1987-1989.<ref name="NN-02Jan2018">{{cite news|title=Former Crewe Alexandra coach Paul McCann facing indecent assault charges|url=http://thenantwichnews.co.uk/2018/01/02/former-crewe-alexandra-coach-paul-mccann-facing-indecent-assault-charges/|accessdate=2 January 2018|work=Nantwich News|date=2 January 2018}}</ref> McCann, from Great Sutton in Cheshire, appeared at Chester Crown Court on 31 January<ref name="BBC-03Jan2018">{{cite news|title=Former Crewe coach charged with indecently assaulting boy|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-42556383|accessdate=3 January 2018|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|date=3 January 2018}}</ref> when he denied the charges and was released on unconditional bail.<ref name="BBC-31Jan2018">{{cite news|title=Former Crewe Alexandra coach denies sex offences|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-42885109|accessdate=8 February 2018|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=31 January 2018}}</ref> He again denied the charges when his trial at Chester Crown Court began on 8 October,<ref name="Taylor-8Oct2018">{{cite news |last1=Taylor |first1=Daniel |title=Crewe youth coach abused boy over three-year period, court told |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/oct/08/crewe-youth-coach-abused-boy-over-three-year-period-court-told |accessdate=8 October 2018 |work=Guardian |date=8 October 2018}}</ref> and on 18 October 2018 was acquitted of all charges.<ref name="Taylor-18Oct2018">{{cite news |last1=Taylor |first1=Daniel |title=Former Crewe coach Paul McCann found not guilty of sexually abusing player |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/oct/18/paul-mccann-crewe-not-guilty-sexual-abuse-player-barry-bennell |accessdate=19 October 2018 |work=Guardian |date=18 October 2018}}</ref>
===Michael "Kit" Carson=== On 27 January 2017, it was reported that (after Higgins) a second former Peterborough United coach had been arrested during investigations into historical sexual abuse. Michael Sean "Kit" Carson, 73, was held in Cambridge on suspicion of indecency with children and indecent assault;<ref name="Morris-27Jan2017">{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Steven|title=Ex-Peterborough United coach arrested in sexual abuse investigation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jan/27/man-arrested-in-investigation-into-historical-sexual-abuse-in-football|accessdate=29 January 2017|work=The Guardian|date=27 January 2017}}</ref> the following day, he was released on bail until 6 March.<ref name="BBCCarsonbail-28Jan2017">{{cite news|title=Ex-coach 'Kit' Carson bailed in historical abuse probe|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-cambridgeshire-38782657|accessdate=29 January 2017|work=BBC News|date=28 January 2017}}</ref>
Carson worked at [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] from 1983 until 1993, and was academy director at Peterborough from 1993 to 2001 (overlapping with Bob Higgins for almost a year), before leaving to become head of talent development at [[Cambridge United F.C.|Cambridge United]] from 2001 to 2005.<ref name="Morris-27Jan2017" />
====2018 charges==== On 2 March 2018 it was announced that Carson had been charged with 11 counts of indecent assault and one of inciting a child to engage in sexual activity. The alleged offences all involved boys under 16, and were said to have occurred from 1978 to 2009.<ref name="bbc-02Mar2018">{{cite news|title=Michael 'Kit' Carson: Ex-football coach charged with abuse of 11 boys|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-cambridgeshire-43257168|accessdate=2 March 2018|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=2 March 2018}}</ref> Carson, 74, appeared at Cambridge magistrates' court on 17 April 2018, pleading not guilty to the 12 charges,<ref name="Morris-17Apr2018">{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Steven|title=Football coach Kit Carson pleads not guilty to child sexual offences|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/apr/17/football-coach-kit-carson-pleads-not-guilty-to-child-sexual-offences|accessdate=17 April 2018|work=Guardian|date=17 April 2018}}</ref> then appeared at Peterborough crown court on 15 May 2018 when he was released on bail pending an administrative hearing on 20 July 2018 ahead of a yet-to-be-determined trial date.<ref name="BBC-15May2018">{{cite news|title=Michael 'Kit' Carson: Ex-football coach denies child sex abuse charges|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-cambridgeshire-44125571|accessdate=15 May 2018|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=15 May 2018}}</ref>
===Ted Langford=== On 30 January 2017, former [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] trainee [[Tony Brien]] told the BBC that he had been abused from the age of 12 by club scout Ted Langford in the 1980s while at local youth team Dunlop Tigers (Langford had been named in allegations which surfaced in December 2016).<ref name="Winter-8Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Winter|first1=Henry|title=Leicester and Villa part of abuse inquiry|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/leicester-and-villa-part-of-abuse-inquiry-zm7d52223|accessdate=7 February 2017|work=The Times|date=8 December 2016}}</ref> Brien said he had been assaulted on the pretext that the scout needed the player's sperm to establish whether he had a "footballer's gene". When Langford moved to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], Brien says he had "two or three" conversations with the club's former assistant manager Dave Richardson and another senior figure, but was put off from going public with the allegations.<ref name="Reed-Ray-30Jan2017">{{cite news|last1=Reed|first1=Jim|last2=Ray|first2=Louis Lee|title=Aston Villa did not report abusive scout to police|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38770506|accessdate=30 January 2017|work=BBC News|date=30 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="BrienAbuse-30Jan2017">{{cite news|title=Football child sex abuse: Tony Brien describes ordeal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38798702|accessdate=30 January 2017|work=BBC News|date=30 January 2017}}</ref> In September 2017, it was reported that [[Graham Taylor]] (then manager of Aston Villa, and later manager of [[England national football team|England]]) had discouraged Brien from reporting what had happened, telling him that he should "move on".<ref name="Taylor-13Sep2017">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Graham Taylor involved in sexual abuse cover-up at Aston Villa, inquiry told|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/13/graham-taylor-sexual-abuse-cover-up-aston-villa|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=Guardian|date=13 September 2017}}</ref>
Langford was sacked by Aston Villa in 1988. He later admitted sex offences, dating from 1976 until after he left the club in 1989; he was sentenced to three years in prison in 2007 for the sexual abuse of four young players (excluding Brien) in the 1970s and 80s. He died in 2012.<ref name="Reed-Ray-30Jan2017" /><ref name="BrienAbuse-30Jan2017" />
===Harry Dunn=== On 24 March 2017, it was reported that 84-year-old former youth football scout Harry Dunn, who had worked at [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] and Chelsea, had been arrested by Scottish police investigating allegations of historical sex abuse.<ref name="BBC-24Mar2017">{{cite news|title=Former football youth scout arrested on sex charges|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-39379347|accessdate=24 March 2017|work=BBC News|agency=BBC|date=24 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="PA-24Mar2017">{{cite news|title=Former scout arrested in historical football sexual abuse investigation|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/mar/24/ex-scout-arrested-historical-football-sexual-abuse-investigation|accessdate=24 March 2017|work=The Guardian|agency=Press Association|date=24 March 2017}}</ref> In February 2017, Dunn had been the subject of allegations by a former Rangers youth player, Darren Mixon, concerning an incident in 1984.<ref name="Herald-20Feb2017">{{cite news|title=Former Rangers youth scout in historic sex probe|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/15103543.Former_Rangers_youth_scout_in_historic_sex_probe/|accessdate=24 March 2017|work=The Herald|date=20 February 2017}}</ref> In November 2017, it was reported that Dunn had died.<ref name="BBC-20Nov2017">{{cite news|title=Ex-youth football scout facing abuse charges dies|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-42055555|accessdate=7 January 2018|work=BBC Scotland|date=20 November 2017}}</ref>
===James Torbett=== {{see also|Big Jock Knew}} James Torbett, a former [[Celtic Boys Club]] manager, was found guilty in 1998 of shameless and indecent conduct with three juvenile players between October 1967 and March 1974,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/213063.stm |title=Former Celtic manager guilty of abuse |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=12 November 1998 |accessdate=19 September 2010}}</ref><ref name=anger>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12364258.Celtic_Boys_apos__Club_founder_guilty_of_shameless_indecency_Anger_over_allegations_suggesting_that_Jock_Stein_was_involved_in_20_year_cover_up/|title=Celtic Boys' Club founder guilty of shameless indecency; Anger over allegations suggesting that Jock Stein was involved in 20-year cover-up|work=[[The Herald (Scotland)|The Herald]] |date=13 November 1998|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> and given a prison sentence of 30 months.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2005/sep/18/childrensservices.crime |title=Child abusers who shame British football |work=[[The Observer]] |last=Bentham |first=Martin |date=18 September 2005 |accessdate=19 September 2010}}</ref> In April 2017, a [[BBC Scotland]] programme ''Football Abuse: The Ugly Side of the Beautiful Game'', alleged that the reasons for Torbett leaving Celtic Boys' Club in 1974 were covered up, that Torbett was allowed to return to the Boys' Club, and that two youth players (one named as Kenny Campbell) were abused by Torbett in his second spell at the Boys' Club during the 1980s and 1990s - claims which Torbett has "vehemently" denied.<ref name="Daly-11Apr2017">{{cite news|last1=Daly|first1=Mark|title=New allegations in football abuse scandal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/uk-scotland-39557101/new-allegations-in-football-abuse-scandal|accessdate=12 April 2017|work=BBC News|date=11 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=New Celtic Boys' Club sex abuse allegations against Jim Torbett revealed|url=https://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/15216616.amp/|work=[[Evening Times]] |date=11 April 2017|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> Tracked down in America, Torbett was confronted by a BBC Scotland reporter about the Campbell allegations; he said: "I have a lot to say. I'll see him in court," and denied being a [[Pedophilia|paedophile]].<ref name="Daly-02May2017">{{cite news|last1=Daly|first1=Mark|title=Ex-Celtic Boys Club coach accused of abuse tracked to US|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-39774853|accessdate=2 May 2017|work=BBC Scotland|date=2 May 2017}}</ref>
====2017 charges==== In early May 2017, following a visit from [[United States Department of Homeland Security|US Homeland Security]], he returned to the UK;<ref name="Daly-03May2017">{{cite news|last1=Daly|first1=Mark|title=Ex-Celtic Boys Club coach accused of abuse returns to UK|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-39797325|accessdate=4 May 2017|work=BBC Scotland|publisher=BBC|date=3 May 2017}}</ref> he was subsequently arrested and charged with six offences (three of indecent assault and three of lewd, indecent and libidinous practices), and on 5 May 2017 appeared at [[Glasgow Sheriff Court]] where he was released on bail.<ref name="STV-5May2017">{{cite news|title=Ex-Celtic Boys Club coach charged over sex offences|url=https://stv.tv/news/west-central/1387729-ex-celtic-boys-club-coach-charged-over-sex-offences/|accessdate=8 May 2017|work=STV|date=5 May 2017}}</ref> In April 2018, Torbett appeared at the High Court in Glasgow where he faced 12 historical sexual abuse charges dating from January 1970 to August 1994; a June 2018 trial date was set.<ref name="McLaren-05Apr2018">{{cite news|last1=McLaren|first1=Andy|title=Ex-Celtic Boys Club coach to stand trial on abuse charges|url=https://stv.tv/news/west-central/1411830-ex-celtic-boys-club-coach-to-stand-trial-over-sex-offences/|accessdate=6 April 2018|work=STV News|date=5 April 2018}}</ref>
====2018 trial and conviction==== The trial, expected to last 10 days, started on 25 June 2018, with Torbett denying all charges.<ref name="BBCScot-25Jun2018">{{cite news |title=Trial hears of football ground links to child sex attacks |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-44601516 |accessdate=26 June 2018 |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=25 June 2018}}</ref> On 4 July 2018, a [[contempt of court]] order was issued regarding the case.<ref>{{cite web |title=Contempt of Court Orders |url=https://www.scotcourts.gov.uk/current-business/court-notices/contempt-of-court-orders|accessdate=14 October 2018 |publisher=[[Scottish Courts and Tribunals Service]] |date=}}</ref> On 22 October 2018, Torbett went on trial again at [[Glasgow High Court]], charged with nine offences of sexual assault on six children between 1970 and 1990.<ref name="Anderson-22Oct2018">{{cite news |last1=Anderson |first1=Deborah |title=Man goes on trial accused of historic sexual abuse of four young boys |url=https://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/17000120.man-goes-on-trial-accused-of-historic-sexual-abuse-of-four-young-boys |accessdate=23 October 2018 |work=Evening Times |date=22 October 2018}}</ref> On 5 November 2018, he was found guilty of five offences against three boys and was sentenced to six years in prison.<ref>{{cite news|title=Celtic Boys Club founder guilty of abuse|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-46098908|work=BBC News |date=5 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=HMA v James Torbett|url=http://www.scotland-judiciary.org.uk/8/2088/HMA-v-James-Torbett|publisher=[[Judiciary of Scotland]] | date=5 November 2018|accessdate=8 November 2018 |}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Celtic Boys' Club founder Jim Torbett had long history of abusing boys|url=https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/celtic-boys-club-founder-jim-13538699|author1=Grant McCabe|author2=Ashlie McAnally|date=5 November 2018|work=Daily Record|accessdate=8 November 2018 }}</ref>
===Gordon Neely=== The same BBC Scotland programme also made new allegations against Gordon Neely (who died in 2014), a youth coach at Rangers in the 1980s who, after abuse allegations were made, had been "dismissed immediately," the Glasgow club said.<ref name="BBC-Offside-05Dec2016" /> Neely had also been accused by former youth player Colin Anderson of abuse at Edinburgh youth club [[Lothian Thistle Hutchison Vale F.C.|Hutchison Vale]].<ref name="STV-06Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Former youth footballer tells of sexual abuse by Scots coach|url=https://stv.tv/news/east-central/1374970-former-youth-footballer-tells-of-sexual-abuse-by-scots-coach/|accessdate=9 December 2016|work=STV News|date=6 December 2016}}</ref> According to the BBC, youth player Jon Cleland was repeatedly raped by Neely while at Hutchison Vale and at [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] (Neely took up a youth development position with Hibs in around 1983).<ref name="Daly-11Apr2017" /> After abuse allegations were made against Neely in 1986, he was sacked, but subsequently joined Rangers where his abuse continued. After he left Rangers in about 1990, he allegedly continued to abuse young players when offering one-to-one training and activity weekends in [[Dunkeld]] and [[Dalguise]], Perthshire, for young footballers.<ref name="Daly-11Apr2017" />
===Gerald King=== In mid April 2017, Gerald King, a former chairman of Celtic Boys Club, was charged by police with non-recent sexual offences.<ref name="GL-14Apr2017">{{cite news|title=Former chairman of Celtic Boys Club suspended from job as primary school teacher after historical sex abuse allegations|url=http://www.glasgowlive.co.uk/news/glasgow-news/former-chairman-celtic-boys-club-12893353|accessdate=8 May 2017|work=Glasgow Live|date=14 April 2017}}</ref> In February 2018, he pleaded not guilty to seven offences, and was bailed.<ref name="BBCScot-06Feb2018">{{cite news|title=Primary teacher in court over 1980s sex abuse allegations|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-42967425|accessdate=4 April 2018|work=BBC News|agency=BBC|date=6 February 2018}}</ref> His bail was extended at hearings at Glasgow Sheriff Court on 17 April<ref name="Mitchell-21Jun2018">{{cite news |last1=Mitchell |first1=Jenness |title=Glasgow teacher Gerald King accused of sexually abusing school children |url=http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/16164822.Glasgow_primary_teacher_accused_of_sexually_abusing_pupils/ |accessdate=21 June 2018 |work=Evening Times |date=17 April 2018}}</ref> and 23 May 2018.<ref name="BBC-23May2018">{{cite news |title=Former teacher accused of abuse at Glasgow primary school |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-44224644 |accessdate=21 June 2018 |work=BBC News |date=23 May 2018}}</ref> King's trial began on 26 November 2018 at Glasgow Sheriff Court. King, 66, was accused of lewd and libidinous practices towards five boys and two girls while he was a teacher at a Glasgow school, between August 1983 and June 1989; he was also charged with taking or permitting to be taken indecent images of children between January 1987 and December 1988 at [[Barrowfield]] football park in Glasgow.<ref name="McAnally-27Nov2018">{{cite news |last1=McAnally |first1=Ashlee |title=Ex-teacher on trial for sex offences |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/ex-teacher-on-trial-for-sex-offences-vx0nv7tfw |accessdate=27 November 2018 |work=Times}}</ref>
===Frank Cairney=== In late April 2017, Frank Cairney, 82, a former Celtic Boys Club coach and manager (who, in November 1998, had been acquitted of charges of shameless indecency towards young football players due to lack of evidence),<ref name="Herald-07Nov1998">{{cite news|title=Celtic Boys' Club manager acquitted|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12250472.Celtic_Boys_apos__Club_manager_acquitted/|accessdate=4 April 2018|work=Herald Scotland|date=7 November 1998}}</ref> was charged in connection with six alleged historical sexual offences.<ref name="BBC-25Apr2017">{{cite news|title=Ex Celtic Boys Club official faces sex abuse charge|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-39713012|accessdate=28 April 2017|work=BBC Scotland|agency=BBC|date=25 April 2017}}</ref> He appeared at [[Hamilton, South Lanarkshire|Hamilton]] Sheriff Court on 11 May 2018, facing ten charges of alleged abuse between 1965 and 1986, including indecent assault, gross indecency and lewd, indecent and libidinous practices and behaviour. A trial date was not set as Cairney's defence team requested three months delay to investigate witness statements; a further pre-trial hearing was scheduled for 10 August 2018.<ref name="MT-14May2018">{{cite news |title=Sexual abuse trial subject to long delay |url=https://www.motherwelltimes.co.uk/news/crime/sexual-abuse-trial-subject-to-long-delay-1-4739109 |accessdate=21 June 2018 |work=Motherwell Times |date=14 May 2018}}</ref>
===Robert Smith=== Robert Smith was jailed for 27 months in 2016 for sexually abusing three boys aged between nine and 12 who played for a football team he was coaching in the [[Easterhouse]] area of [[Glasgow]] in the 1980s. In June 2018, he pleaded guilty to six further charges: four charges of using lewd and libidinous practices and two charges of indecent assault.<ref name="ET-24Jun2018">{{cite news |title=Robert Smith: Glasgow paedophile admits to abusing boys as young as NINE |url=http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/16310744.robert-smith-glasgow-paedophile-admits-to-abusing-boys-as-young-as-nine/ |accessdate=27 June 2018 |work=Evening Times |date=24 June 2018}}</ref> On 13 July 2018, Smith, 69, was sentenced to 20 months in prison.<ref name="McAnally-13Jul2018">{{cite news |last1=McAnally |first1=Ashlie |title=Victim of paedophile football coach Robert Smith slams 'lenient' sentence of 20 months |url=https://www.glasgowlive.co.uk/news/glasgow-news/victim-paedophile-football-coach-robert-14906256 |accessdate=17 August 2018 |work=Glasgow Live |date=13 July 2018}}</ref>
===William Toner=== On 20 July 2018, William Toner, 74, was jailed for three years and two months on four counts of indecent assault against a teenage boy in the 1990s. A trial heard he preyed on a junior footballer after claiming to work for Manchester City and having links to clubs in Bury, Rochdale, Oldham and Cambridgeshire.<ref name="Taylor-20Jul2018">{{cite news |last1=Taylor |first1=Daniel |title=Manchester City investigate if newly jailed sex abuser had links to club |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jul/20/manchester-city-investigate-sex-abuser-links-william-toner-barry-bennell |accessdate=20 July 2018 |work=Guardian |date=20 July 2018}}</ref>
===Michael Coleman=== Also on 20 July 2018, Michael Coleman, 75, was jailed for seven years on three counts of indecent assault at [[Bolton]] Crown Court. He was unconnected to any senior club when he committed his crimes in the 1980s while he was manager of [[Westhoughton]] Sports Centre.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-manchester-44904068 Westhoughton: former football coach jailed for abusing boys - BBC News, 20 July 2018]</ref>
===Other alleged abusers=== Alleged abusers also included (in alphabetical order): * Former Hampshire FA chief Ray Barnes, involved in inquiries into Bob Higgins's conduct, was later convicted of indecently assaulting three boys.<ref name="BBC-06Dec2016" /> * John Broome (now dead) was named by Manchester City as someone allegedly engaged in sexual abuse at a [[Levenshulme]]-based feeder team Whitehill FC (now defunct), with an ex-player claiming damages from City.<ref name="Pilling-20Feb2018">{{cite news |last1=Pilling |first1=Kim |last2=Scheerhout |first2=John |title=Coach John Broome could have abused hundreds of boys, claims former youth footballer |url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/coach-john-broome-could-abused-14314092 |accessdate=28 June 2018 |work=Manchester Evening News |date=20 February 2018}}</ref> * John Hart (died in 1995), physiotherapist at [[Partick Thistle F.C.|Partick Thistle]], was dismissed in 1992 over sex abuse allegations.<ref name="STV-07Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Partick Thistle sacked physio over sex abuse allegations|url=https://stv.tv/news/west-central/1375084-partick-thistle-sacked-physio-over-sex-abuse-allegations/|accessdate=9 December 2016|work=STV News|date=7 December 2016}}</ref> [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]] also launched an investigation into alleged historical sexual abuse as Hart had also worked at the Fir Park club.<ref name="Motherwell-09Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Motherwell FC launch child sexual abuse investigation|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-38269138|accessdate=10 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=9 December 2016}}</ref> * Chris Gieler (who died in 2004), youth development manager and chief scout during a 32-year career at [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], was also named in historical child abuse allegations.<ref name="BBC-QPR-06Dec2016" /> * David King, convicted in 1997 of sexual offences against a 10-year-old pupil at the school where he was the headteacher, was an associate of George Ormond at Newcastle's Montagu and North Fenham boys football club.<ref name="Conn/Parveen-06Dec2016" /> * Frank Roper (now dead) ran Stockport-based feeder club, Nova,<ref name="Roper-01Dec2016"/> was also associated with [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Identity of paedophile football coach revealed|url=http://www.itv.com/news/update/2016-12-01/identity-of-paedophile-football-coach-revealed/|accessdate=3 December 2016|work=ITV News|publisher=ITV|date=1 December 2016}}</ref> and was the subject of complaints by Paul Stewart and Jason Dunford, plus groping allegations by former [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] player [[Jamie Forrester]].<ref name="Sims-04Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Sims|first1=Alexandra|title=Ex-Southampton coach accused by six former players as football sex abuse scandal widens|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/southampton-bob-higgins-former-coach-named-in-connection-historic-sexual-abuse-claims-continue-grow-a7455561.html|accessdate=5 December 2016|work=The Independent|date=4 December 2016}}</ref>
==Response and investigations==
===Football bodies===
====Football Association==== On 21 November 2016, the [[Football Association]] said it was setting up a helpline;<ref name="Taylor-21Nov2016" /> this was established with the [[National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children|NSPCC]] and opened on 24 November,<ref name="PA-24Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Press Association|title=NSPCC launches hotline for sexually abused footballers|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/nov/24/nspcc-launches-hotline-for-sexually-abused-footballers|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=24 November 2016}}</ref> reportedly receiving over 50 calls within the first two hours,<ref name="Cacciottolo-25Nov2016" /> over 100 by 27 November,<ref name="BBCSexAbuse-27Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Sex abuse: Football Association to investigate allegations|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38121724|accessdate=27 November 2016|work=BBC|publisher=BBC|date=27 November 2016}}</ref> and 860 ("more than three times as many referrals as in the first three days of the [[Jimmy Savile sexual abuse scandal|Jimmy Savile scandal]]") by 1 December<ref name="Hotline-1Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Football abuse hotline receives 'staggering surge' in calls|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38161301|accessdate=1 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=1 December 2016}}</ref> with 350 individuals alleging abuse.<ref name="Dodd-350-1Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Dodd|first1=Vikram|title=Police say 350 people have come forward to report child sex abuse in football|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/01/fa-punish-clubs-cover-up-martin-glenn|accessdate=1 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=1 December 2016}}</ref> After three weeks, the call total had reached 1700.<ref name="NSPCC-15Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Rawlinson|first1=Kevin|title=NSPCC football abuse hotline receives over 1,700 calls in 3 weeks|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/dec/15/nspcc-football-abuse-hotline-receives-over-1700-calls-in-3-weeks|accessdate=15 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=15 December 2016}}</ref> The FA and NSPCC also collaborated to produce a film about how to keep children safe in the sport, featuring the captains of England's men's, women's and cerebral palsy football teams ([[Wayne Rooney]], [[Steph Houghton]] and Jack Rutter).<ref name="BBCfilm-03Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Football sex abuse: England captains make child safety film|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38185414|accessdate=3 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=3 December 2016}}</ref>
After the Hamilton Smith interview suggesting the FA failed to thoroughly investigate Crewe's system, on 27 November, the FA announced it was to set up an internal review, led by independent counsel Kate Gallafent QC, into what Crewe and Manchester City knew about Barry Bennell and allegations of child sexual abuse in football, and investigate what information it was aware of at the time of the alleged offences.<ref name="Guardian-27Nov2016">{{cite news|title=FA sets up review into child sex abuse in football after Barry Bennell claims|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/27/fa-review-child-sex-abuse-football-barry-bennell-claims|accessdate=27 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=27 November 2016}}</ref>
The FA was criticised by Conservative MP [[Damian Collins]], chair of the House of Commons' [[Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee|Culture, Media and Sport Committee]], for being too slow in reacting and not instigating a wider review.<ref name="BBC-28Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Football Association child sex abuse review 'not enough'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38128570|accessdate=28 November 2016|work=BBC|date=28 November 2016}}</ref> Former sport minister [[Gerry Sutcliffe]] talked of previous concern about how the FA dealt with governance of the sport and with youth development (in the 1990s, the FA was said to have reacted "dismissively" to worries about sexual abuse in the game, and too slow to implement criminal record checks;<ref name="Reed-08Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Reed|first1=Jim|last2=Ray|first2=Louis Lee|title=Football abuse: FA reacted 'dismissively' to protection calls|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38242317|accessdate=8 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=8 December 2016}}</ref> in 2003, the FA had scrapped a project meant to ensure children were being protected from sexual abuse;<ref name="Reed-30Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Reed|first1=Jim|title=FA 'pulled all funding' from child protection project|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38145061|accessdate=3 December 2016|work=BBC|date=30 November 2016}}</ref> and FA officials had been uncooperative with the review project, with ten of 14 FA staff not replying to interview requests and a report by the researchers of others being "prevented/bullied" from talking).<ref name="Taylor-1Apr2017" /> Sutcliffe said an independent body, such as the [[Department for Culture, Media and Sport]], should look at the issue rather than the FA investigating itself: "What I've seen in football over the years is that they're very narrow, very insular, and may not do a proper job even though with the right intentions."<ref name="BBC-Soton-03Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Southampton 'abuser' still working in football|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38191644|accessdate=3 December 2016|work=BBC News|agency=BBC|date=3 December 2016}}</ref>
On 6 December 2016, the FA announced that, due to "the increased scope of the review since it was announced"<ref name="FA-TOR-06Dec2016">{{cite web|title=Terms of reference for review into alleged non-recent child sexual abuse in football|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2016/dec/05/fa-statement-terms-of-reference-061216#U2v6Wmb00hyAKYda.99|website=Football Association|publisher=FA|accessdate=6 December 2016}}</ref> and Gallafent's other professional commitments, the review would be conducted by Clive Sheldon QC.<ref name="BBC-06Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Harry Redknapp criticises FA over coach claims|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38218377|accessdate=6 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=6 December 2016}}</ref> On the same day, it was announced that former Chelsea assistant manager Dario Gradi would be among the first to be targeted by the FA's enquiry over the "smoothing over" allegation,<ref name="FAGradi-06Dec2016"/> and five days later the FA announced Gradi had been suspended.<ref name="FAGradi-11Dec2016" /><ref name="BBC-FA-Gradi-11Dec2016" /><ref name="Rawlinson-12Dec2016" /> Almost three months later, in February 2017, it was reported that Gradi planned to appeal against his FA suspension from football, feeling he had been left "in limbo".<ref name="Conway-27Feb2017">{{cite news|last1=Conway|first1=Richard|title=Dario Gradi: Crewe director of football to appeal against FA suspension|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39103246|accessdate=27 February 2017|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=27 February 2017}}</ref>
On 5 January 2017, it was reported that the FA had suspended former Crewe youth coach Paul McCann.<ref name="McCannsuspension-5Jan2017"/>
The FA collaborated with other UK sports bodies to support the NSPCC's Child Protection in Sport Unit (CPSU), founded in 2001 following various 1990s revelations of abuse, most notably in swimming. Brunel University's Daniel Rhind said the FA is today seen as a leading sports governing body for child protection with the system put in place since the CPSU was formed regarded as a “gold standard” model other countries can follow.<ref name="Conn re Brackenridge-29Dec2016" /> In December 2016, the FA said that 99% of its 7,814 grassroots clubs, covering 62,238 teams, had responded to a deadline to renew their safeguarding policies and commitment.<ref name="Conn re Brackenridge-29Dec2016" /> On 6 January 2017, the FA said 99.7% of clubs' coaches had valid criminal records checks but more than 2,500 coaches were without an in-date CRC, and so these clubs were facing potential suspension and removal of their FA affiliation.<ref name="Dennis-6Jan2017">{{cite news|last1=Dennis|first1=Ian|title=Football sex abuse: Junior clubs must get coaches cleared or face suspension|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38537776|accessdate=19 January 2017|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=6 January 2017}}</ref>
On 11 January 2017, it was reported that the FA's review, led by Clive Sheldon, had made its first call for evidence, writing to all football clubs in England and Wales, amateur and professional, asking for information about allegations of child sexual abuse between 1970 and 2005. Clubs had until 15 March 2017 to respond.<ref name="PA-11Jan2017">{{cite news|title=Review into child abuse in football makes first call for evidence|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jan/11/review-into-allegations-child-abuse-in-football-first-call-for-evidence|accessdate=12 January 2017|work=The Guardian|date=11 January 2017}}</ref> The FA's inquiry was expected to last around a year to 18 months.<ref name="Taylor-13Apr2017" /> In May 2017, eight (unnamed) professional clubs were reported to have failed to respond to the FA's call for evidence, despite a deadline extension to the end of April,<ref name="Taylor-15May2017">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Football abuse scandal: eight clubs could face sanctions after missing deadlines|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/may/15/football-abuse-scandal-eight-clubs|accessdate=16 May 2017|work=The Guardian|date=15 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="BBC-16May2017">{{cite news|title=Child sex abuse: Eight football clubs fail to respond to inquiry|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39936217|accessdate=16 May 2017|work=BBC Sport|date=16 May 2017}}</ref> as investigators started to search 5,000 boxes of FA archives - each containing up to 1,000 pages.<ref name="Roan-15May2017">{{cite news|last1=Roan|first1=Dan|title=Child sex abuse: Inquiry team to search through 5,000 boxes of FA archives|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39928510|accessdate=16 May 2017|work=BBC Sport|date=15 May 2017}}</ref> Sheldon issued a fresh appeal for victims of sexual abuse in football to come forward in July 2017.<ref name="Taylor-23Jul2017">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=QC makes fresh appeal for victims of sexual abuse in football to come forward|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jul/23/sexual-abuse-football-investigation-clive-sheldon-appeal-for-victims|accessdate=24 July 2017|work=The Guardian|date=23 July 2017}}</ref> In October 2017, it was reported that six county Football Associations had not responded to requests for information five months after being asked to do so, while the volume of material involved would delay the final report until after Easter 2018.<ref name="Rumsby-16Oct2017">{{cite news|last1=Rumsby|first1=Ben|title=Six County FAs fail to respond to questions on football sex abuse|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/10/16/six-county-fas-fail-respond-questions-football-sex-abuse/|accessdate=20 October 2017|work=Telegraph|date=16 October 2017}}</ref> Ongoing criminal proceedings against Bennell, Higgins and others were also likely to limit what could be covered in the report.<ref name="Rumsby-16Oct2017" /> Sheldon and other members of the enquiry team were reported to be receiving counselling after hearing some victims' abuse accounts.<ref name="Kelner-16Oct2017">{{cite news|last1=Kelner|first1=Martha|title=FA inquiry leader receives counselling after hearing victims’ accounts of abuse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/oct/16/fa-abuse-inquiry-head-clive-sheldon-counselling?CMP=share_btn_tw|accessdate=20 October 2017|work=Guardian|date=16 October 2017}}</ref> In March 2018, it was reported that the scale of evidence provided, plus the "chaotic nature of the archiving", had delayed the inquiry team's sift through the FA's legal files; around 500,000 pages of material from 6,000 files were uploaded to a digital platform, and 353 documents were identified as highly relevant. All 46 county FAs had responded to the inquiry. Sheldon expected to start writing his final report in August 2018.<ref name="Steinberg-28Mar2018">{{cite news |last1=Steinberg |first1=Jacob |title=FA sexual abuse inquiry head ready to investigate any clubs who fail to cooperate |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/mar/28/fa-child-sexual-abuse-inquiry-investigate-clubs-clive-sheldon-qc |accessdate=18 July 2018 |work=Guardian |date=28 March 2018}}</ref>
