In October 2017, FA chairman [[Greg Clarke]] was criticised by Andy Woodward for 'humiliating' remarks Clarke made to a Digital, Culture, Media and Sport select committee hearing,<ref name="Rumsby-25Oct2017">{{cite news|last1=Rumbsy|first1=Ben|title=Greg Clarke under fire again as abuse survivor Andy Woodward accuses FA chairman of 'humiliating' him|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/10/25/greg-clarke-fire-abuse-survivor-andy-woodward-accuses-fa-chairman/|accessdate=30 October 2017|work=Telegraph|date=25 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="BBC-26Oct2017">{{cite news|title=Woodward 'devastated & deeply upset'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41768651|accessdate=30 October 2017|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|date=26 October 2017}}</ref> while the [[Professional Footballers' Association]]'s chief executive [[Gordon Taylor (footballer)|Gordon Taylor]] said the PFA might sue Clarke over suggestions Taylor had not supported Woodward with further counselling.<ref name="Kelner-26Oct2017">{{cite news|last1=Kelner|first1=Martha|title=PFA’s Gordon Taylor considering legal action against FA chairman Greg Clarke|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/oct/26/fa-chairman-greg-clarke-admits-organisation-has-lost-trust-of-the-public|accessdate=30 October 2017|work=Guardian|date=26 October 2017}}</ref>
In July 2018, it was reported that the FA's independent inquiry had found no evidence of an institutional cover-up or of a paedophile ring operating within football. Sheldon's report, likely to be highly critical of several clubs, was initially expected to be delivered to the FA in September 2018,<ref name="Taylor-26Jul2018">{{cite news |last1=Taylor |first1=Daniel |title= FA sexual abuse inquiry finds no evidence of institutional cover-up |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jul/26/fa-sexual-abuse-inquiry-clive-sheldon |accessdate=30 July 2018 |work=Guardian |date=26 July 2018}}</ref> but its publication was delayed, potentially by up to a year, pending the retrial of Bob Higgins and possible further charges against Barry Bennell.<ref name="Taylor-26Sep2018">{{cite news |last1=Taylor |first1=Daniel |title=Football sexual abuse scandal review may be delayed for more than a year |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/sep/26/football-sexual-abuse-scandal-review-may-be-delayed-over-a-year |accessdate=26 September 2018 |work=Guardian |date=26 September 2018}}</ref>
====Other bodies==== Eight days after Woodward's initial revelations, the PFA said on 24 November 2016 that the number of players who had contacted it with similar stories had reached double figures,<ref name="PA-24Nov2016" /> later (27 November) revising this to "more than 20"<ref name="BBC-27Nov2016" /> and adding [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] and Leeds United to the list of clubs implicated.<ref name="PFA-27Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Leeds and Blackpool named by Gordon Taylor in child sex abuse in football scandal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/27/leeds-blackpool-gordon-taylor-child-sex-abuse-scandal|accessdate=27 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=27 November 2016}}</ref> In January 2017, it was reported that Steve Walters had been on a course of counselling at the [[Priory Group|Priory]] provided by the PFA.<ref name="Wallace-5Jan2017">{{cite news|last1=Wallace|first1=Sam|title=Silence from current players over child sex abuse claims has been deafening, says Steve Walters who hopes they can follow lead of Wolves captain Dave Edwards|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/01/04/silence-current-players-child-sex-abuse-claims-has-deafening/|accessdate=5 January 2017|work=Telegraph|date=4 January 2017}}</ref>
On 7 December 2016, [[Premier League]] boss [[Richard Scudamore]] wrote to the parents of more than 3,000 players in the league's youth system to reassure them regarding child protection.<ref name="98total-09Dec2016" /> On 23 December 2016, it was reported that Chelsea had not broken Premier League rules in failing to report 2014 allegations of historical sexual abuse made by Gary Johnson, but would undergo a safeguarding audit.<ref name="PLrules-22Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Goodwin|first1=Stuart|title=Chelsea cleared of breaking rules in handling of Gary Johnson abuse case|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/22/chelsea-cleared-breaking-rules-gary-johnson-abuse|accessdate=23 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=22 December 2016}}</ref>
After the Hugh Stevenson allegations emerged, [[Scottish Football Association]] chief executive [[Stewart Regan]] apologised "deeply" to Peter Haynes.<ref name="Daly-05Dec2016" /> Former SFA chief executive [[Gordon Smith (footballer, born December 1954)|Gordon Smith]],<ref name="exSFA-08Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Scottish Football Association 'should hold abuse inquiry'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-38248118|accessdate=9 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=8 December 2016}}</ref> civil rights lawyer Raju Bhatt<ref name="98total-09Dec2016" /> and [[Deputy First Minister of Scotland|Deputy First Minister]] [[John Swinney]]<ref name="BBCSwinney-11Dec2016">{{cite news|title=John Swinney urges SFA inquiry into football abuse claims|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-38281185|accessdate=11 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=11 December 2016}}</ref> all called for an independent inquiry after [[First Minister of Scotland|Scottish First Minister]] [[Nicola Sturgeon]] rejected calls for an existing inquiry to be widened.<ref name="1stMin-08Dec2016">{{cite news|title=First minister rejects call to widen abuse inquiry|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-38252157|accessdate=9 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=8 December 2016}}</ref> On 13 December 2016, the SFA said it would set up an "independent review" of child abuse allegations in football;<ref name="BBC-SFAinquiry-13Dec2016">{{cite news|title=SFA to establish football abuse review|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-38308254|accessdate=13 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=13 December 2016}}</ref> on the same date, of 15,385 coaches registered with the Scottish Youth Football Association, 2,500 had not had Protecting Vulnerable Groups (PVG) clearance,<ref name="Daly-13Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Daly|first1=Mark|title=No checks on 2,500 youth football coaches|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-politics-38308253|accessdate=13 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC}}</ref> though this backlog was largely cleared ahead of a 31 August 2017 deadline.<ref name="ETimes-27Aug2017" /> In February 2017, it was reported that the SFA's enquiry would be headed by Martin Henry, formerly a police protection chief and national manager of child sexual abuse prevention charity Stop it Now! Scotland.<ref name="PP-3Feb2017">{{cite news|title=Ex-force executive officer to kick-start football's abuse investigation|url=http://www.policeprofessional.com/news.aspx?id=28380|accessdate=17 March 2017|work=PoliceProfessional.com|date=3 February 2017}}</ref>
In Manchester on 5 December 2016, abuse victims Andy Woodward, Steve Walters, Chris Unsworth, Matthew Monaghan and Mark Williams launched a support organisation, the Offside Trust, to support player victims of abuse and their families<ref name="BBC-Soton-03Dec2016" /><ref name="BBC-Offside-05Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Sex abuse footballers 'want to be free of pain'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38211017|accessdate=5 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=5 December 2016}}</ref> (though it is unclear if this body is to become a registered charity).<ref name="Herbert-2Mar2017">{{cite news|last1=Herbert|first1=Ian|title=Football is not rife with child abusers, so it is time for the Offside Trust to explain what they are for|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/premier-league-football-abuse-offside-trust-explain-andy-woodward-a7606486.html|accessdate=2 March 2017|work=The Independent|date=1 March 2017}}</ref> At the launch, the Trust's lawyer Ed Smethurst talked of alleged abusers still working "in the senior echelons" of football, of "grave misgivings about the FA's independent inquiry", and of new claims that clubs had paid 'hush money'.<ref name="Taylor-05Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Prominent football figures still in game named by players alleging sexual abuse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/05/football-sexual-abuse|accessdate=6 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=5 December 2016}}</ref> On 3 February 2017, it was announced that Woodward was stepping away from the Trust, having resigned as a director.<ref name="Eurosport-3Feb2017">{{cite news|title=Andy Woodward leaves Offside Trust but campaign gains momentum|url=http://asia.eurosport.com/football/andy-woodward-leaves-offside-trust-but-campaign-gains-momentum_sto6046917/story.shtml|accessdate=3 February 2017|work=Eurosport|date=3 February 2017}}</ref> On 20 August 2017, a celebrity football match was played at [[Curzon Ashton F.C.]] in Manchester to raise funds for the Trust.<ref name="OffsideTrust match">{{cite web|title=Celebrity Match|url=http://www.theoffsidetrust.com/celebrity-match|website=Offside Trust|accessdate=30 October 2017}}</ref>
===Football clubs=== Dario Gradi's 24 November statement mentioned Crewe Alexandra had established an internal review,<ref name="Gradi-24Nov2016" /> and the club subsequently announced it would be holding an independent review into how they dealt with historical child sex abuse allegations: "an independent review, to be conducted via the appointment of external legal counsel, is the correct way forward".<ref name="BBC-27Nov2016" /><ref name="Townsend-26Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Townsend|first1=Mark|title=Crewe to launch independent review into handling of child abuse allegations|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/26/crewe-independent-review-handling-child-abuse-allegations|accessdate=27 November 2016|work=The Observer|date=26 November 2016}}</ref> In February 2018, the club had not started this review, claiming an unnamed authority told them to hold off until the criminal case was over.<ref name="Taylor-15Feb2018"/> On 2 March 2018, the club issued a statement saying that, as it had fully supported and co-operated with the police's detailed and comprehensive investigations, it did "not intend to commission a further independent investigation to duplicate the thorough enquiries that have already been undertaken," and said the police's report had also been supplied to the FA review headed by Clive Sheldon.<ref name="CAFC statement-02Mar2018">{{cite web|title=Club Statement: Barry Bennell (2)|url=https://www.crewealex.net/news/2018/march/club-statement-barry-bennell-2/|website=CreweAlex.net|accessdate=2 March 2018}}</ref> Crewe's decision to shelve its own investigation was criticised by local MP [[Laura Smith (politician)|Laura Smith]] (daughter of former club director Hamilton Smith) who said victims deserved nothing less than a thorough investigation which "should be transparent and leave no stone unturned."<ref name="Ryan-09Mar2018">{{cite news|last1=Ryan|first1=Belinda|title=MP urges Crewe Alex to hold independent investigation into historic handling of child sex predator Barry Bennell|url=https://www.crewechronicle.co.uk/news/mp-urges-crewe-alex-hold-14387725|accessdate=9 March 2018|work=Crewe Chronicle|date=9 March 2018}}</ref> The club was also excluded from the NorthWest Football Awards, was criticised by Damian Collins, chair of the DCMS select committee,<ref name="Drucker-14Mar2018">{{cite news|last1=Drucker|first1=James|title=Crewe's refusal to conduct internal Barry Bennell inquiry is 'totally unacceptable', says Damian Collins|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/03/14/crewes-refusal-conduct-internal-barry-bennell-inquiry-totally/|accessdate=21 March 2018|work=Telegraph|date=14 March 2018}}</ref> and by [[Crewe Town Council]],<ref name="Ryan-13Mar2018">{{cite news|last1=Ryan|first1=Belinda|title=Crewe Alex refusal to hold inquiry 'demonstrates a disregard for Bennell's victims' town council leader says|url=https://www.crewechronicle.co.uk/news/crewe-alex-refusal-hold-inquiry-14407864|accessdate=14 March 2018|work=Crewe Chronicle|date=13 March 2018}}</ref> and was called to reconsider its decision by the PFA's Gordon Taylor.<ref name="Taylor-10Mar2018">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Crewe excluded from regional awards for handling of Barry Bennell scandal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/mar/10/crewe-barry-bennell-excluded-northwest-football-awards|accessdate=11 March 2018|work=Observer|date=10 March 2018}}</ref>
Manchester City said it had opened an investigation regarding Bennell's association with the club in the 1980s;<ref name="Cacciottolo-25Nov2016" /> in May 2017, it was reported this was being led by Jane Mulcahy QC.<ref name="Taylor-15May2017" /> Stoke said they were ready to launch an investigation into any allegation raised.<ref name="Herbert-25Nov2016" /> On 25 November, [[Northumbria Police]] said their inquiries were "ongoing", while Newcastle United said it would cooperate with the police and relevant authorities.<ref name="Rumsby-25Nov2016" /> On 29 November, [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] announced it had appointed a law firm to carry out an investigation connected to allegations of historical sexual abuse in the 1970s;<ref name="Guardian-chelsea30Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Chelsea open investigation into historical sex abuse allegations|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/29/chelsea-investigation|accessdate=30 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=29 November 2016}}</ref> it was later reported that Chelsea's review was being chaired by Charles Geekie QC, a specialist in child abuse cases.<ref name="Taylor-15May2017" />
The FA's enquiry also linked to club enquiries. In May 2017, FA letters were sent to almost 20 clubs linked to the scandal to establish if they are holding their own reviews and, if not, why not. Clubs including Chelsea, Manchester City, Newcastle United, Southampton, Aston Villa, Blackpool and Crewe Alexandra were asked to submit evidence to Sheldon's own review.<ref name="Taylor-15May2017" /> In March 2018, Clive Sheldon warned up to a dozen clubs they must hold their own investigations into abuse claims or he will do it, putting pressure on Crewe to reconsider its decision not to hold an inquiry.<ref name="Eurosport-28Mar2018">{{cite news|title=Clive Sheldon tells clubs he will investigate abuse claims if they fail to do so|url=https://www.eurosport.co.uk/football/clive-sheldon-tells-clubs-he-will-investigate-abuse-claims-if-they-fail-to-do-so_sto6693614/story.shtml|accessdate=29 March 2018|work=Eurosport News|agency=PA|date=28 March 2018}}</ref>
===Police=== Initially, Cheshire police were reported to be liaising with [[Greater Manchester Police]] over the allegations,<ref name="Rumsby-25Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Rumsby|first1=Ben|title=Jason Dunford and Chris Unsworth break silence as English football's child sex abuse crisis deepens|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/11/25/man-city-launch-investigation-english-footballs-child-sex-abuse/|accessdate=25 November 2016|work=Telegraph|date=25 November 2016}}</ref> with the Manchester force later confirming it was launching an investigation and co-operating with [[Operation Hydrant]], the national co-ordination hub for historical child abuse investigations concerning persons of public prominence.<ref name="Morris-28Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Steven|title=Greater Manchester police investigates claims of sex abuse in youth football|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/28/greater-manchester-police-investigates-historical-sex-abuse-youth-football|accessdate=29 November 2016|work=The Guardian|date=28 November 2016}}</ref> On 26 November [[Hampshire Constabulary|Hampshire Police]] said it was looking into claims of "non-recent child abuse within the football community", while the [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] also opened investigations.<ref name="BBC-26Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Football sex abuse: Crewe 'knew of claims against Bennell'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38113288|accessdate=26 November 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=26 November 2016}}</ref> By 1 December, [[Staffordshire Police]], [[Police Scotland]],<ref name="Mendick-30Nov2016" /> [[Essex Police]], [[Norfolk Constabulary|Norfolk Police]]<ref name="Fifield-30Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=Fifield|first1=Dominic|title=Police 'opted against action' over Chelsea ex-player's sex abuse claim|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/30/police-opted-against-action-over-chelsea-ex-players-sex-abuse-claim|accessdate=30 November 2016|work=Guardian|date=30 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="14Forces-BBC-30Nov2016">{{cite news|title=Fourteen police forces investigate football sex abuse claims|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38161301|accessdate=30 November 2016|work=BBC|publisher=BBC|date=30 November 2016}}</ref> and [[North Wales Police]] were reported to be among 17 forces examining claims of historical sex abuse in football.<ref name="Dodd-350-1Dec2016" /> On 6 December 2016, the [[Police Service of Northern Ireland]] became the 21st UK police force to confirm it was investigating claims.<ref name="BBC-QPR-06Dec2016" /> On 13 December 2016, the Metropolitan Police said it was investigating 106 allegations of historical sexual abuse at 32 London football clubs (including four in the Premier League, two in the Championship, three against clubs in Leagues One and Two and 21 other clubs including non-league or non-professional or amateur teams).<ref name="Met-13Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Grierson|first1=Jamie|last2=Brooks|first2=Libby|title=Met police receive 106 allegations of sexual abuse at football clubs|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/13/met-police-106-allegations-of-sexual-abuse-at-london-football-clubs|accessdate=13 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=13 December 2016}}</ref> Some six weeks later (30 January 2017), the Met were reported to be investigating 255 separate allegations against individuals at 77 clubs, including all five London Premiership teams.<ref name="Brunt-30Jan2017">{{cite news|last1=Brunt|first1=Brunt|title=Football abuse: All top London clubs investigated|url=https://news.sky.com/story/football-abuse-all-top-london-clubs-investigated-police-10749291|accessdate=30 January 2017|work=Sky News|date=30 January 2017}}</ref>
By 3 December 2016, 55 professional and non-league clubs had been cited by people claiming they were abused.<ref name="Townsend-03Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Townsend|first1=Mark|title=Football abuse scandal grows with 55 clubs now involved|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/03/football-abuse-scandal-grows-55-clubs-now-involved|accessdate=4 December 2016|work=The Observer|date=3 December 2016}}</ref> On 9 December 2016, the [[National Police Chiefs' Council]] (NPCC) said 83 potential suspects and 98 clubs were involved in the inquiry into child abuse;<ref name="98total-09Dec2016">{{cite news|title=Football abuse claims extend to 98 clubs|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38260878|accessdate=9 December 2016|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|date=9 December 2016}}</ref> on 21 December 2016, the NPCC's figures were updated to 155 suspects and 148 clubs, with detectives said to be examining possible attacks on 429 people.<ref name="NPCC-21Dec2016">{{cite web|title=National statistics on allegations of non-recent child sexual abuse in football: Updated 21/12/16|url=http://www.npcc.police.uk/NPCCBusinessAreas/OtherWorkAreas/OpHydrant/FootballAbuseStats.aspx|website=National Police Chiefs' Council|accessdate=21 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="Dodd-21Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Dodd|first1=Vikram|title=Football sexual abuse victims may have been as young as four years old – police|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/21/football-sexual-abuse-young-victims|accessdate=21 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=21 December 2016}}</ref> The "higher than usual" volume of calls was said to be delaying police interviews and investigations,<ref name="BBCWoodward-22Dec2016"/> with some respondents waiting more than a month; the first wave of victims waited an average of six weeks to be interviewed.<ref name="PA-11Jan2017"/> The increase in allegations of child sexual abuse linked to football led Cheshire Police to ask the [[Home Office]] for extra funding.<ref name="McCann-29Mar2017">{{cite news|last1=McCann|first1=Phil|title=Cheshire Police in funding request over football-related child sex probes|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-manchester-39424791|accessdate=2 May 2017|work=BBC News Manchester|date=29 March 2017}}</ref>
On 18 January 2017, the NPCC said the number of affected clubs had grown to 248, up 100 since its December 2016 update. It said Operation Hydrant had received 1,016 referrals from the NSPCC and from police forces (up from 819), and had identified 184 suspects and 526 potential victims, of whom 97% are male, with ages ranging from four to 20 when the alleged abuse took place.<ref name="Topping-19January2017">{{cite news|last1=Topping|first1=Alexander|title=More than 240 clubs now involved in football sexual abuse scandal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jan/18/police-confirm-500-potential-victims-sex-abuse-football?CMP=share_btn_tw|accessdate=19 January 2017|work=The Guardian|date=18 January 2017}}</ref> In April 2017, Operation Hydrant was reported to have received over 400 new referrals since January, bringing the total to 1,432 referrals, and was investigating complaints involving 311 clubs, 23% of them professional.<ref name="Taylor-13Apr2017">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Police investigating child abuse in football receive 400 new referrals|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/apr/12/police-investigation-child-abuse-in-football-400-new-referrals|accessdate=13 April 2017|work=The Guardian|date=12 April 2017}}</ref> The NPCC said the number of victims at 31 March 2017 stood at 560 (96% of them male), with 252 suspects identified.<ref name="NPCC-18Apr2017">{{cite news|title=National statistics on allegations of non-recent child sexual abuse in football: Up to and including 31/03/17|url=http://www.npcc.police.uk/NPCCBusinessAreas/OtherWorkAreas/OpHydrant/FootballAbuseStats.aspx|accessdate=18 April 2017|work=NPCC|date=18 April 2017}}</ref> Up to 30 June 2017, Police Scotland said over 150 people had reported being sexually abused as a child within a football club setting, 295 crimes had been recorded, and 11 people had been arrested.<ref name="STV-10Jul2017">{{cite news|title=Police arrest 11 as part of football sex abuse inquiry|url=https://stv.tv/news/scotland/1393218-police-arrest-11-as-part-of-football-sex-abuse-inquiry/|accessdate=11 July 2017|work=STV|date=10 July 2017}}</ref> According to NPCC figures, a total of 741 alleged victims had come forward by 30 June 2017, with 276 suspects named, 1,886 incidents reported and 328 clubs at every level of football affected.<ref name="Taylor-23Jul2017" /> The figures were updated on 28 September 2017,<ref name="NPCC-28Sep2017">{{cite web|title=Operation Hydrant - football abuse statistics up to and including 28 September 2017|url=http://www.npcc.police.uk/NPCCBusinessAreas/OtherWorkAreas/OpHydrant/FootballAbuseStats.aspx|website=National Police Chiefs' Council|accessdate=20 October 2017|ref=28 September 2017}}</ref> and 31 December 2017, recording 839 alleged victims, 294 alleged suspects, arising from 2094 referrals, impacting 334 clubs.<ref name="BBC-After-15Feb2018">{{cite news|title=After Barry Bennell convictions, where now for football's sexual abuse scandal?|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42993689|accessdate=16 February 2018|work=BBC|publisher=BBC|date=15 February 2018}}</ref> In July 2018, police figures were reported to have identified 300 suspects, 849 alleged victims, and 2,807 incidents involving 340 different clubs.<ref name="Taylor-20Jul2018"/>
As well as football, 27 referrals of victims were made from other sports including basketball, rugby, gymnastics, martial arts, tennis, wrestling, golf, sailing, athletics, cricket, and swimming.<ref name="Topping-19January2017" /><ref name="NPCC-28Sep2017" />
In April 2017, it was reported that Operation Hydrant had received reports of incidents within football after 2005 (the FA inquiry's cut-off date), with 46 alleged attacks said to have occurred from 2005 to 2016, including 23 since 2011.<ref name="Taylor-1Apr2017">{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Daniel|title=Police receive reports that child abuse is still happening in football|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/apr/01/police-reports-child-abuse-football-operation-hydrant|accessdate=2 April 2017|work=The Observer|date=1 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="Taylor-13Apr2017" />
Police have speculated that the football revelations since 2016 "may" have contributed to an increase in the number of men and boys coming forward to make allegations of rape.<ref name="Tobin-7Oct2018">{{cite news |last1=Tobin |first1=Olivia |title=Number of men and boys reporting rape in London leaped in the same year as football abuse scandal |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/number-of-men-and-boys-reporting-rape-in-london-soared-in-the-same-year-as-football-abuse-scandal-a3954656.html |accessdate=10 October 2018 |work=Evening Standard |date=7 October 2018}}</ref>
===Government=== On 16 November 2017, almost exactly a year after the scandal first emerged, the [[Minister for Sport and Civil Society|sports minister]] [[Tracey Crouch]] announced that the [[Ministry of Justice]] had agreed changes to the law to make it illegal for sport coaches to have sex with 16- and 17-year-old children in their care, bringing the sport industry into line with sectors such as education and social care.<ref name="Kelner-16Nov2017">{{cite news|last1=Kelner|first1=Martha|title=Law to change to make sex between coaches and 16- and 17-year-olds illegal|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/nov/16/law-change-coaches-relationships-16-17-year-olds-illegal|accessdate=17 November 2017|work=Guardian|date=16 November 2017}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Penn State child sex abuse scandal]], similar case in the U.S. where assistant American football coach [[Jerry Sandusky]] was convicted of molesting boys

[[Falmouth, Jamaica|Falmouth]], [[Jamaica]] | capacity = 3,000 | chrtitle = President | chairman = {{flagicon|JAM}} [[Daine Thomas]] | manager = {{flagicon|JAM}} [[Preston Bernard]] | coach = | kit manufacturer = Joma | main sponsor = JustBet | league = [[Western Confederation (Level 2 on football pyramid)]] | season = 2014-15 | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=_thinredsides|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=FFFFFF|body1=FFFFFF|rightarm1=FFFFFF|shorts1=FF0000|socks1=FF0000 | pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2= | leftarm2=DAA520|body2=DAA520|rightarm2=DAA520|shorts2=800000|socks2=DAA520 }} '''Village United Football Club''' is a [[Jamaica]]n [[Football (soccer)|football]] team playing at the 2nd level of the football pyramid in Jamaica which is regional placing the club in the Western Confederation. The other regional areas are Eastern Confederation, South Central Confederation and Kingston and St. Andrew Confederation(KASFA). The club is based in [[Falmouth, Jamaica|Falmouth]] and their current home stadium is the Elleston Wakeland Stadium in Falmouth, which can hold a capacity of 3,000. The club moved from Falmouth's [[Elleston Wakeland Stadium]] in the 2010-2011 season to the Trelawny Multi Purpose Stadium that had a capacity of 25,00 but were back there after relegation in the 2011-2012 season.[http://falmouthphotos.info/falmouth-albums/events/sports/photos-village-united-fc-first-home-game-trelawny-multi-purpose-stadium/ First home game at Trelawny Multi-Purpose Stadium] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926225559/http://falmouthphotos.info/falmouth-albums/events/sports/photos-village-united-fc-first-home-game-trelawny-multi-purpose-stadium/ |date=September 26, 2011 }} - Falmouthphotos The team has never won the [[Jamaican National Premier League|National Premier League]]. ==History== Village United F.C was formed on September 8, 1968 in an area of Falmouth called Village or Compound. The area is located opposite the [[Elleston Wakeland Stadium]]. ===Achievements=== A-league champions 2001-2003 == Notable former players == *{{flagicon|Jamaica}} [[Winston Anglin]] † *{{flagicon|Jamaica}} [[Shane Crawford (soccer player)|Shane Crawford]] *{{flagicon|Jamaica}} [[Lance Laing]] *{{flagicon|Jamaica}} [[Jason Morrison (footballer)|Jason Morrison]] *{{flagicon|Jamaica}} [[Donovan Ricketts]] *{{flagicon|Jamaica}} [[Newton Sterling]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071227030320/http://www.golocaljamaica.com/premierleague/scores/team_profile.php?tid=7 Team profile] - Golocaljamaica *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110617062836/http://brianelliott.me/index.php/Sports/Village-United-FC Village Photos] - Village United FC PHOTOS *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080928152346/http://villageufc.com./ Village United] - Official team website {{Jamaican Soccer}} [[Category:Football clubs in Jamaica]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1968]] [[Category:1968 establishments in Jamaica]] {{Jamaica-footyclub-stub}}

{{For|other stadiums known as '''War Memorial Stadium'''|War Memorial Stadium (disambiguation)}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = War Memorial Stadium | nickname = | image = | fullname = | location = [[Wailuku, Hawaii]] | coordinates = {{Coord|20|53|33.97|N|156|29|19.68|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=inline}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1969 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = | seating_capacity = 23,000 | dimensions = }} '''War Memorial Stadium''' is a [[stadium]] located in [[Wailuku, Hawaii]] that opened in 1969 and holds 23,000 people. It is primarily used for [[American football]], and from 1998 through 2005 was the venue for the [[Hula Bowl]], a [[college football]] all-star game. When the stadium originally opened in 1969 it held fewer than 7,000 people. It was expanded due to the efforts of the then-mayor of Maui, [[Linda Lingle]], to host the Hula Bowl.
The War Memorial Stadium is also home to the [[Maui Interscholastic League]] (MIL) High School Football association. The stadium is also equipped with a state of the art 440 yard track, long jump, triple jump, high jump, and pole vaulting pits. In 1972, the stadium was the site of the first State High School Track and Field Championships held outside of [[Honolulu]], chosen in part because of the new state of the art rubberized [[asphalt]] surface.
Adjacent to the War Memorial Stadium is a 1,500 plus seat [[Maehara Stadium]], that is home to the [[Maui Interscholastic League]] Baseball and American Legion Games.
The War Memorial Stadium Complex houses training facilities for H.P. Baldwin High School, Soccer, and Softball Fields, Soichi Sakamoto Pool, and a 2,000 plus seat gymnasium. The complex was dedicated in 1965 to honor the Veterans of Maui County (comprising the Islands of Maui, Moloka'i and Lana'i) who gave their lives in service of their country.
The Stadium complex is located on the windward side of the island between the towns of [[Kahului]] and the county seat [[Wailuku]], on the Valley Isle of [[Maui]] and is adjacent to H.P. [[Henry Perrine Baldwin High School|Baldwin High School]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{More footnotes|date=June 2014}} '''White-collar boxing''' is a form of [[boxing]] in which men and women in [[White-collar worker|white-collar professions]] train to fight at special events. Most have had no prior boxing experience.
==Early history== White-collar boxing has its beginnings at [[Gleason's Gym]] in [[New York City]]. Gym owner Bruce Silverglade began organizing informal fights between the white-collar workers of his clientele in the late 1980s, which later developed into regular monthly events. After developing into a regular monthly event, the sport came to prominence in the mid-1990s under the organization of boxing promoter Alan Lacey.<ref name=economist>{{cite web |url=http://www.economist.com/node/3908985 |title=White men can box |last=McAuley |first=Tom |work=The Economist |date=12 May 2000 |accessdate=24 Jun 2014}}</ref> By 2004 over 65% of Gleason's Gym membership was from a [[White-collar worker|white-collar]] background, compared to 10% in the early 1990s. The increase of membership from this demographic has been credited with maintaining the profitability of boxing gyms in the US and UK.<ref name=bw>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2004-11-28/out-of-the-office-into-the-ring |title=Out of the Office, Into the Ring |last1=Hindo |first1=Brian |last2=Cohn |first2=Laura |work=Business Week |date=28 Nov 2004 |accessdate=24 Jun 2014}}</ref>
Event management consultant Alan Lacey, who co-promoted the [[Gary Stretch]] vs. [[Chris Eubank]] [[World Boxing Organization|WBO]] middleweight championship bout in 1991, belatedly discovered boxing training at the age of 45. Captivated and motivated by the discipline over the following years, he started training under former European champion Jimmy McDonnell and alongside two-time Olympian and world title challenger Adrian Dodson, who having spent most of his youth at Gleason’s Gym in New York suggested Lacey to fulfill his ambition to box, even at the age of 48, and arranged for him to visit Gleason's and box there. On the flight back to London, Lacey decided white-collar boxing could flourish in London. {{Citation needed|date=June 2012}}
In July 2000, the inaugural white-collar boxing event, "Capital Punishment", in collaboration with Gleason's owner Bruce Silverglade, saw a team of Wall Street bankers fly to London to compete at Broadgate Arena in London, generating interest and media coverage. Lacey boxed twice on the night and subsequently devoted his time and energy to developing the sport exclusively since. Over 100 sold-out events have followed "Capital Punishment", including "Celebrity Boxing" on the BBC in 2003 featuring, among others, [[Les Dennis]] and [[Ricky Gervais]], and raising more than [[Pound sterling|UK₤]]1.5 million for various charities. {{Citation needed|date=June 2012}}
==In the Asia–Pacific region== {{expand section|with=history of the sport in the region|date=June 2014}}
The many bouts in the Asia–Pacific region are usually contested under WWCBA ''(see below)'' sanctioning.
==Governing bodies== {{Unreferenced section|date=June 2012}}
In 2001, Lacey and Bruce Silverglade co-founded the '''International White Collar Boxing Association''' (IWCBA),<ref>[http://www.economist.com/node/3908985 'White men can box' economist.com]</ref> the first and to this day main advisory and sanctioning [[Sport governing body|governing body]] in the field, designed to regulate the bouts with a focus on safety. The IWCBA uses the same weight divisions of professional boxing and awards a belt to the champions of each weight category. Matchmaking of non-title bouts is based on level of experience as much as actual weight. It also rigorously requires the presence of an experienced doctor, an [[anesthetist]], and a paramedic unit at ringside as well as thorough medical checks. Over 1,500 bouts have been sanctioned by the IWCBA over the years, with zero injuries aside from bloody noses. IWBCA-sanctioned bouts are predominant in the UK and US.
In 2007, the '''World White Collar Boxing Association''' (WWCBA) was founded to London, UK, to regulate and promote the sport throughout the world, but is principally active in the Asia–Pacific region. The WWCBA provides a common platform in the form of rules and guidelines allowing boxers to become ranked nationally, regionally and globally and to contest for championship titles. In 2008 the WWCBA sanctioned 9 events throughout the world. The WWCBA works with other boxing authorities such as the amateur [[International Boxing Association (amateur)|International Boxing Association]] (AIBA) to ensure strong standards.<ref>[http://wwcba.org/about.html About the WWCBA wwcba.org]</ref>
==Bouts== {{Unreferenced section|date=June 2012}}
Bouts are usually three 2-minute rounds ("3×2" format), unlike the longer three 3-minute rounds (3×3) in the Amateur Code for men and 4×2 format for women. The IWCBA bouts have traditionally been "no decision" draws (ties) in absence of a knock-out, while WWCBA ranking system requires a win-loss decision for all bouts.
The first large gala events included the [[Boodles Boxing Ball]] series attended by Prince Harry as well as the "Hedge Fund Fight Nite" raising over $200,000 for charity both is initially organized/staged by The Real Fight Club.
In 2005 a purely non-profit black-tie gala at the London Hilton organized by The David Adams Leukaemia Appeal Fund & Mr King with more than 950 black-tie dinner guests raised over £100,000 for The Royal Marsden Hospital Cancer Campaign on the night. It was the largest event of its kind until 2013, see below.
In April 2009 a gala at Suntec Singapore Exhibition and Convention Centre staged by Vanda Promotions had more than 900 black-tie guests.
On Saturday, 18 July 2009, the Channel Island of Jersey held its first white-collar-boxing event. Nine fights were watched by over 600 paying, black-tied guests at the Hotel de France, raising around £15,000 for local charities.
Ultra White Collar Boxing (UWCB) are the largest company organising events in the UK. They held the largest event in November 2014 with 3000 spectators, they hold events in over 100 towns and cities across the UK and have raised over £16,000,000 to date for Cancer Research UK. They also held the largest event in the UK with over 3,500 guest at an event in Coventry in 2015. UWCB organise over 250 events a year with an average of 15,000 people taking part each year.
On 13 October 2012, [http://www.neilsonboxing.co.uk Neilson Boxing], a Swindon-based white-collar-boxing promoter, put on the largest show of its kind to date. A venue verified attendance of 1398 watched ten contests at the Oasis Leisure Centre in Swindon with the main event seeing Dave 'Bam Bam' Gregory retain his NP Heavyweight title against Rich 'The Tank' Loveday over three rounds. This was surpassed in March 2014 when a crowd of nearly 2,000 fight fans saw 'Sugar' Shawn Grant defeat ex-pro Phill Day to gain the Vacant Cruiserweight Title.
On 20 April 2013, Vanda Promotions (part of Vanda Sports Group) held its twenty-fourth event in Singapore making the series the longest consecutive white-collar boxing in the history of the sport. A verified attendance of 1,943 attended the black-tie event at the Raffles Convention Centre which brought total attendance over the five-year history of the events to 15,491. The event also saw Vanda move past the $2 million mark for funds raised for children's charities in Asia and for the continued funding of the Vanda Wing at Children's Surgical Centre in Cambodia. Vanda was also the recipient of the "Promoter of the year award" for the fourth consecutive year from the World White Collar Boxing Association (WWCBA).
===YouTube Boxing Championship=== {{See|KSI vs. Logan Paul}}
On 3 February 2018, two British [[YouTuber]]s, [[KSI (entertainer)|KSI]] and {{ font colour | red | Joe Weller }}, fought at [[Copper Box Arena]] in [[London]], England, where KSI defeated Weller by [[technical knockout]]. At its peak, 1.6 million viewers tuned in live, making it the UK boxing's largest live audience since [[Anthony Joshua vs. Wladimir Klitschko]] in April 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5350035/YouTube-stars-boxing-match-draws-1-6-million-viewers.html|title=YouTubers fight Britain's biggest boxing match in a year as 1.6M watch|last=|first=|date=4 February 2018|work=Mail Online|access-date=2018-02-18|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> On [[YouTube]], the KSI vs. Weller fight drew 21{{nbsp}}million views on fight night,<ref>{{cite news |title=KSI Vs Weller Got Over 20 Million Views On YouTube Last Night |url=http://www.ladbible.com/news/uk-sport-ksi-vs-weller-got-over-20-million-views-on-youtube-20180204 |work=[[LADbible]] |date=4 February 2018 |language=en}}</ref> and over 25{{nbsp}}million over the next several days, becoming the biggest white-collar boxing fight in history.<ref>{{cite news |title=KSI Reveals What He Said to Joe Weller in the Ring During a Breakdown of the YouTuber Boxing Fight |url=https://www.dexerto.com/news/ksi-reveals-said-joe-weller-ring-breakdown-youtuber-boxing-fight/43707 |work=Dexerto |date=7 February 2018}}</ref> KSI was awarded the YouTube Boxing Championship Belt.
KSI fought American YouTube personality [[Logan Paul]] in [[KSI vs Logan Paul|a white-collar boxing match on 25 August 2018]]. One judge scored in favour of KSI and two judges scored a draw, resulting in a [[majority draw]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Who won KSI vs Logan Paul fight? Result from YouTube boxing fight in Manchester |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/boxing/who-won-ksi-logan-paul-13131170 |work=mirror |date=25 August 2018}}</ref> The fight has been labeled "the largest event in YouTube history"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M5LyCOgrzoA|title=THE BIGGEST EVENT IN INTERNET HISTORY...|first=|last=MoreSidemen|date=24 August 2018|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/ksi-vs-logan-paul-weigh-in-youtube-fight-how-to-watch-free-stream-live-a8506131.html|title=KSI and Logan Paul weigh-in ahead of 'biggest internet event in history'|last=Hamdani|first=Adam|date=25 August 2018|website=[[The Independent|Independent]]|access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> and "the largest ever amateur boxing fight".<ref name="radio-times">{{cite web|author=Radio Times Staff|title=KSI v Logan Paul: why are YouTube’s biggest stars going to fight in the boxing ring?|url=https://www.radiotimes.com/news/on-demand/2018-08-22/ksi-v-logan-paul-boxing-fight-date-live-stream-youtube/|website=[[Radio Times]]|accessdate=2018-08-23|date=2018-08-22|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Equipment== Sixteen-[[ounce]] gloves are standard in the white-collar-boxing ring in order to protect competitors from heavy blows and hand injuries. Some gyms permit 14 oz gloves as well for lighter weight classes and for female competitors. Moreover, headgear, groin protectors, and mouthguards are obligatory requirements inside the ring.<ref>[http://truewhitecollarboxing.com/general/white-collar-boxing-rules/ Example of white collar boxing rules at truewhitecollarboxing.com]</ref>
==Death== On 21 June 2014, white-collar boxer Lance Ferguson-Prayogg collapsed following a fight at The Forum nightclub in Nottingham, England. Paramedics were called, and he was taken to hospital, but died the next day.<ref>{{cite web|title=Boxer dies after boxing bout at The Forum|url=http://www.nottinghampost.com/Boxer-dies-boxing-bout-Forum/story-21278711-detail/story.html|website=Nottingham Post|publisher=Nottingham Post|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tributes to 'white-collar' boxer Lance Ferguson-Prayogg|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-nottinghamshire-27991351|website=BBC website|publisher=BBC|accessdate=24 June 2014}}</ref> An inquest ultimately attributed his death to the use of diet pills, not boxing.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-nottinghamshire-32595607 "'White collar' boxer death caused by diet drugs", from bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-nottinghamshire] Retrieved 2 October 2016</ref>

{{Infobox Stadium | name = William B. Greene Jr. Stadium | nickname = | image = [[File:ETSU Football Stadium Home Side.jpg|250px]] | former_names = | location = 1300 Jack Vest Drive
[[Johnson City, Tennessee|Johnson City]], [[Tennessee]] | coordinates = {{coord|36.299|-82.374|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = November 16, 2015{{cite web |url=http://wjhl.com/2015/11/16/groundbreaking-ceremony-held-for-etsus-new-football-stadium/|title=Groundbreaking ceremony held for ETSU’s new football stadium|work=[[WJHL-TV|WJHL]]|date=November 16, 2015|accessdate=December 19, 2015}} | built = | opened = September 2, 2017 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[East Tennessee State University]] | operator = East Tennessee State University | surface = Artificial turf | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]26,615,000 | architect = McCarty Holsaple McCarty, Inc.{{cite web |title=New Football Stadium for East Tennessee State University|url=http://www.etsu.edu/facilities/documents/2incover.pdf|publisher=East Tennessee State University|date=December 30, 2015|accessdate=September 16, 2017}}
John Fisher Architect | structrual engineer = John L. Jacobs & Associates | services engineer = Facilities Systems Consultants, LLC | general_contractor = BurWil Construction Co. | capacity = 7,694 | tenants = [[East Tennessee State Buccaneers football|ETSU Buccaneers]] football }} '''William B. Greene Jr. Stadium'''{{cite press release|url=http://www.etsubucs.com/football/news/2017-18/14135/board-approves-naming-of-william-b-greene-jr-stadium/ |title=Board approves naming of William B. Greene, Jr. Stadium |publisher=East Tennessee State Buccaneers |date=August 24, 2017|accessdate=August 24, 2017 }} is a football stadium on the campus of [[East Tennessee State University]] (ETSU) in [[Johnson City, Tennessee|Johnson City]], [[Tennessee]]. The stadium is named after businessman and longtime ETSU supporter [[William B. Greene Jr]]. Located on the southwestern corner of campus at the foot of Buffalo Mountain, the new stadium is expected to have a seated capacity of over 7,000, plus standing room for an additional 3,000, and will cost roughly $26.615 million. The stadium is home to the newly resumed [[East Tennessee State Buccaneers football]] team, which played their [[2015 East Tennessee State Buccaneers football team|2015]] and [[2016 East Tennessee State Buccaneers football team|2016]] seasons at [[Kermit Tipton Stadium]] on the campus of [[Science Hill High School]]. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FCS football stadiums]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://etsustadium.com/ ETSU Football Stadium official website] {{East Tennessee State Buccaneers football navbox}} {{Southern Conference football venue navbox}} {{Tennessee college football venues}} [[Category:East Tennessee State Buccaneers football venues]] [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Johnson City, Tennessee]] [[Category:American football venues in Tennessee]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2017]]

{{Infobox video game |title = Zumba Fitness 2
Zumba Fitness Rush |image = Zumba-fitness-2-video-game.jpg |caption = |developer =[[Zoë Mode]] |publisher =[[Majesco Entertainment]] |engine = In House |released = '''Wii'''
{{vgrelease |NA|15 November 2011|AUS|24 November 2011|EU|25 November 2011}} '''Xbox 360'''
{{vgrelease|NA|13 February 2012|PAL|24 February 2012}} |genre =[[Exergaming|Fitness game]] |modes =[[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Wii]], [[Xbox 360]] }} '''''Zumba Fitness 2''''' is the second video game in the installment of the Fitness series, based on the [[Zumba]] program. It is also the sequel to ''[[Zumba Fitness (video game)|Zumba Fitness]]'' (2010), later followed by ''[[Zumba Fitness Core]]'' (2012).[http://zumba-reviews.com/zumba-game/zumba-fitness-game-is-it-really-that-good Zumba Game Review] It is developed by [[Zoë Mode]] and was published by [[Majesco Entertainment]]. It was released first on the [[Wii]] in November 2011 and then on [[Kinect]] for [[Xbox 360]] in February 2012 under the title '''''Zumba Fitness Rush'''''.http://www.everybodyplays.co.uk/news/360/Zumba-Fitness-2-announced/608{{cite web|url=http://gamereuphoria.com/2011/10/26/all-posts/majesco-entertainment-announces-zumba-fitness-rush |title=Archived copy |accessdate=October 31, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304030631/http://gamereuphoria.com/2011/10/26/all-posts/majesco-entertainment-announces-zumba-fitness-rush |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }} ==Gameplay== Players can learn and perfect nine different dance styles: [[reggaeton]], [[Merengue (dance)|merengue]], [[Salsa (dance)|salsa]], [[cumbia]], [[Hip-hop dance|hip hop]], [[Mambo (dance)|mambo]], [[rhumba|rumba]], [[flamenco]] and [[Calypso music|calypso]] as well as new routines including the [[Axé (music)|axé]], Indian, [[Latin pop]], [[bellydance]] and [[pasodoble]].http://worthplaying.com/article/2011/8/12/news/82819/ led by [[Zumba]] creator [[Beto Perez|Beto]] and celebrity instructors Gina Grant and [[Tanya Beardsley]]. New features include a calorie tracker, revamped gameplay and graphical representations of the instructors. ==Soundtrack== The game uses licensed tracks for its soundtrack, which includes "[[Pause (Pitbull song)|Pause]]" by [[Pitbull (rapper)|Pitbull]] as the game's theme song. Other songs for the game include a Zumba version of "[[Poison (Nicole Scherzinger song)|Poison]]" by [[Nicole Scherzinger]], and "[[We No Speak Americano]]" by [[Yolanda Be Cool]] & [[DCUP]]. "Pause" is featured uncut on the Wii version, with the Kinect version using the edited "Zumba Mix" of the track. ==Reception== The Xbox 360 version received mainly unfavorable reviews, most notably due to the lack of online multiplayer from ''Zumba Fitness''. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Zumba}} [[Category:2011 video games]] [[Category:Dance video games]] [[Category:Exergames]] [[Category:Kinect games]] [[Category:Majesco Entertainment games]] [[Category:Music video games]] [[Category:Unreal Engine games]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Wii games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United Kingdom]]

The team play in the [[Turkish Women's Handball Super League|Turkish Super League]]. Their colors are blue and white. ==Squad== As of July 2017 {{Col-begin|width=60%}} {{Col-2}} ;Goalkeepers: * {{flagicon|TUR}} [[Zeynep Onur]] * {{flagicon|TUR}} [[Derya Tınkaoğlu]] * {{flagicon|TUR}} Duygu Hamarat ;Wings: * {{flagicon|TUR}} [[Esin Sağdıç]] * {{flagicon|TUR}} Ilayda Baktir * {{flagicon|TUR}} Dilek Yilmaz ;Pivots: * {{flagicon|TUR}} Burcu Çetin * {{flagicon|RUS}} Valentina Goncharova {{Col-2}} ;Backs: * {{flagicon|TUR}} [[Sibel Karameke]] * {{flagicon|TUR}} [[Çağla Yılmaz]] * {{flagicon|TUR}} Burcu Dindar * {{flagicon|TUR}} Aleyna Hati * {{flagicon|Israel}} Amit Izak * {{flagicon|TUR}} Gizem Buse Dalli * {{flagicon|TUR}} Gizem Koca {{Col-end}} ==Notable former players== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[Sevilay İmamoğlu Öcal]] (born 1984) * [[Serpil İskenderoğlu]] (born 1987) * [[Aslı İskit]] (born 1993) * [[Esin Sağdıç]] (born 1988) * [[Duygu Sakallı]] (born 1991) * [[Yasemin Şahin]] (born 1988) * [[Seda Yörükler]] (born 1984) }} ==Honours== ;[[Turkish Women's Handball Super League|Turkish Handball Super League]]: * ''Runner-up'' (1): 2010–11 * ''Third place'' (1): 2007–08 ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |url=http://www.thf.gov.tr/ligler/bayanlar-super-lig |publisher=Türkiye Hentbol Federasyonu |title= Bayanlar Süper Lig |language=Turkish |accessdate=2016-02-07 }} }} {{Turkish Women's Handball Super League}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Izmir Buyuksehir Belediyesi GSK}} [[Category:İzmir Büyükşehir Belediyespor|Handball women's]] [[Category:Turkish handball clubs]] [[Category:Women's handball in Turkey]] {{Turkey-sport-stub}} {{Handball-club-stub}}
